sentence: Anyone who gives this film higher than a 9 lacks integrity, or just has never seen a good movie: A lot of the late dictator's loyalists will hype this film up but its really, really boring
It's not the worst film I've seen but just like most of Darryl Yap's films, it's trash
Much of the acting from Christine Reyes is just her shouting
It's a grating noise to the ears
The maids in the film are the best part of it as the delivery of their lines are somewhat entertaining, however the lines and "hugots" feel so forced and shallow
The main problem is really the script
The emotional scenes feel so forced
It's obviously a propaganda film and a really boring one at that
It had an okay start but dragged so much at the middle almost as if they were trying to fit a bunch of propaganda from a checklist
The soundtrack and cinematography are okay but not enough to salvage the film
Skip it
PUTANGINA: I don't know why people review this movie with 1 star, The movie have good combination of comedy and drama, But I think need more cinematography
Overall the movie is good to watch and not boring but need more improvement
It's okay
: Entertaining but confusing
Chapters are not connected with each other
It felt like broken and scattered
It felt like something made by an amateur
Great idea, poor execution, great acting tho
Ferdinand E Marcos Sr is a great president: This movie shows a president who loves his people
I don't call him a dictator
I call him a great president
The Marcos family became victim of many false accuses
I'm happy they are back
Another Darryl Yap trademark: Political messages aside, the movie editing is messy and incoherent at times
The scene transitions were bad even for a typical Filipino drama

The acting seems forced and the story direction tries too hard but fails to convince viewers to sympathize with the cast because of badly placed comedic banters in between scenes and badly-written script
It seems like the director didn't learn or even try to improve on his filmmaking formula which has already been frowned upon in his previous films
Not even worth it: Honestly, I was expecting a coherent turn of events in this film
However, the lack of cinematography bores me to the point it feels like I'm watching a poorly executed youtube skit
As to the transition of the scenes, it was choppy
At first, I thought I'll get used to it but it turns out to be very unnecessary and annoying
The color grading was ok but I supposed they could have done more in terms of the lighting
Furthermore, the acting was so bland and god it was horrible, in fact one of the actress could not shed a tear in the climax of the film
Nonetheless, the girl with the short hair expresses well with her eyes but her voice screeches sometimes
The dialogues written was plain and bland unfortunately did not engaged us viewers
I was hoping they would take us back to that time but that was not the experience at all
Overall, the movie felt so rush and unproduced
Not even worth your time

: I had an open mind watching this movie
I wanted to give the Marcoses a chance, but I was so wrong
This movie is was not trying to tell the story from the other side
It was a way to manipulate the public, to make the Marcoses look like they were the victims, what a joke
They're trying to cover up the atrocity that the Marcoses did
Stop trying to change the history, it's never gonna work
It's been proven time and time again that truth always win
Non-bitter movie: To those who gave a negative review to this movie, the question is did everyone watch it
Or do you just want to boycott the movie because there is nothing you can do with the strong support of the people in MIM
Well, for those who are anti Marcos, there is nothing new in your dirty works
I can only say that the plot of the story is very good
You will cry, but you will also laugh at other scenes
You're just really bitter
Complete waste of time: Cringy acting
Terrible writing
The score is off-putting
The story is obviously self serving
Not for people who are after a real movie
Its like Vlogging with a punctuation
SO IMPRESSIVE: I love the movie
It shows about what happened in the last days of Marcoses in Palace
I've learned a lot
Thank you for creating this awesome political movie
It made me cry: Please ignore harsh and negative comments about this movie
Most of them only watched the trailer and never bothered to watch the whole film
They are primarily from people who hate the Marcos family
I just watched it last night, and it made me cry
I never expected myself to cry over a biopic, semi-documentary film that depicts the last 72 hours of the family of the leader who has been tagged as a dictator in Philippine history
I don't have much expectation when it comes to local Filipino films
I never bother watching one in the past
But, for this one, I made an exemption
I have watched maybe a thousand movies and foreign tv series; thus, I have a very high standard when rating one
For this film, I rate it 6
5 stars
It's a low-budget movie with a very compelling storyline and dialogue, and I don't want it to end
When it ended, I felt like there were more stories to tell, thus the reason I gave it a 6
5-star rating
Another reason for my rating is that a few scenes are OA
I hope the director can improve his craft in the sequel movie, MoM - Martyr or Murderer
I am very interested to know what the Marcos family's take about the assassination of Benigno Aquino
It could've been better
: I know criticism is your enemy, but let's be honest in here
Apparently, this could've been a good movie if all of these plots and stories were made with true and validated proofs
I could say it's not "bad" to tell the story of the Marcoses-if only they were truthful to what the Marcoses did back-in their last 72-hours in Malacañang
I could say that most of the plot in this movie is just as distorted as ever, although I wanted to hear a single thing that Marcos Sr
Admits his mistakes that he have done to his country back then, but it turns out that this movie came out to be such an anti-climatic, and distorted

I know this is hard to accept, but mocking the Carmelite Sisters playing Mah-Jhong, making Cory falsely say "Let them out of the Philippines" isn't really the most accurate stuff I've ever seen in the movie
There are still missing pieces that I wanted to hear from this movie's script and plot

I could re-watch it again to re-validate the topics above, but no, Daryl Yap, you should've grabbed the history books and read them well-even if it contains your enemies' stories, learn to accept them-accept the truth for everyone to accept your movie, and not keeping up with those beautiful lies to distort the lads
I TRIED: Watched this on the first day of release and was in utter disappointment on how bad the whole film was
Setting the fact that the goal of this film was to distort history, the overall production of the film was bad and mediocre
Some actors stood out with their good performances but clearly wasn't enough to save the whole film
Dialogues are weak and bland
There are no remarkable scenes and yes it's safe to say that I wasted my time watching this but hey
I tried
Stereotype movie: Not worth watching, acting was poor, cinematics are too bland
For a movie that is overly hyped, this movie looks really cheap
I've watched better indie films than this
The title says it all: a version of a tale of one of the most contentious times in modern Philippine history

: The title says it all: a version of a tale of one of the most contentious times in modern Philippine history as told from the point of view of three domestic helpers employed in the dictator: Ferdinand Marcos Senior's Presidential Palace
(This is obviously the root of a recent trending topic on Philippine social media pitting historical accuracy against rumor-mongering - with the clear intent to validate this film's point of view

)

With the involvement in this film's production of a lone, single, individual with the last name 'Marcos,' from the entirety of this point in Philippine history; the film is the embodiment of a lone, single, individual's point of view

Full transparency: this reviewer could only stand the first 30 minutes of the film before storming out because almost all of the events are conveyed through the incessant shouted narration, screamed narration, and complained narration of three fictional maids
Context was totally absent - leaving the viewer to figure out for themselves and navigate the precise point in history that is being portrayed on film
As a witness to this history, even I could not make heads or tails of it

Adding to the confusion, the actors playing their respective roles did not even exert any effort to try to emulate the mannerisms, speech patterns, and idiosyncrasies of the historical characters they are portraying
It's a guessing game, distracting from whatever message the film tries to convey, unless the entire nature of this film's existence is to distract
The constant cutting between re-enactments and historical footage adds to the confusion since no attempt was made to recreate the footage using the actors in the same context
Go figure
This is bad
Really bad
Really, really bad
If you're a masochist wishing and willing to undergo being constantly screamed at by the help, then, by all means, waste your hard-earned money
Darryl Yap is a genius
: After 30+ years, Filipinos were able to hear and understand the other side of the story
Kudos to all cast from Apo Lakay to all helpers in the palace
They're all amazing
I underestimated Ella Cruz but she's a really good actress
I wish the movie had more scenes with Irene Marcos
I also love Christine Reyes
More Marcos movies soon, Direk
Boring and Awkward Acting: Nothing lesson to be learned here

There was no chemistry among the characters
Even a highschool theatre play is better than this
Absolute flop but thanks to the free tix, should have slept at the cinema instead

This is a movie, NOT a biopic
As a movie is has more values, values about family

Art is subjective

A Movie that adds the story from the other persoective: I would like to write this review with no political bias between Pro Marcos and Anti-Marcos as I can;

In the recounts of history about the Marcos Family has been demonized by the media and our historical books about the Martial law, the plot was entirely simple that depicts the last 3 days of the Marcos Family living inside the Presidential Palace
No Historical revisionism has taken place, I said it myself, THERE'S NONE

During the EDSA Revolution in the 1986 every documentary has all-out entirely focused about the Aquino and the People who went out to spurt their anger about how they are sick and tired on the rule of Marcos for the past two decades, the ounce of brutality and the human rights violation during the time of martial law (1972-1981) the mere fact that it was understandable due to the rise of Communism in the 70's and organized terrorist running rampant in the Philippines of why it was declared
When I sat down in cinema frowning down with my expectations quite low

Upon realizing that the movie is comprised with different segments of chapters as if its a book of some sort, another thing I can add-on was that documentaries are lazily panned from the actual movie instead of letting the actual actors/actresses to do their part of the following history
The first Chapters started quite alright upon build-up pacing for the story
This, however went dragging on to the point the chapters were too repetitive, unpolished and very unnecessary
Instead why not derive the Chapters to just 3 settings instead of 10
The First Chapter is the buildup, the second chapter will be the climax, and the third chapter as the aftermath
My most awaited part of the plot was the actual 3 maids that served the Marcos family for 20 years

Beverly Salviejo as Yaya Biday, Elizabeth Oropesa as Yaya Lucy and Karla Estrada as Yaya Santa, which served as the center-piece of the history which proves that this event really happened during the last days of the Marcoses

My only issue with the maids depicted in this movie is portrayed in comedic manner in such a serious movie that tear-jerks your emotion The pacing went downhill when the rallyists stormed the Malacañang in a very comedic manner due to Budgetary constraints
Philippine movies have come a long way to depict a proper practical effects in the movie
I would've gave this film a zero but since I can't, I GIVE IT A ONE: Two words: history revisionism
This is the worst film ever, not only is it history revisionism, I might as well call it historical fiction
I really dislike this film, I enjoy Filipino documentaries because as a Filipina myself, it sparks nationalism in my heart but this movie
Not only did it do the polar opposite of what films usually make me feel but it made me sick to my stomach
This film is truly the worst, I cannot believe many Filipinos praise it as if it doesn't showcase history revisionism
Do not watch this film unless you are used to listening to lies

history revisionism: Maid in Malacañang (2022) Directed by: Darryl Yap

Huling tatlong araw ng mga Marcos sa Malacañang
Ano ang nangyari
The movie didn't give the experience of a family in their last 72 hours
The progression of events is anti-climactic
The flow of conversation is dull
The choice of words is hollow
The storytelling is not cohesive
It feels like you're watching some YouTube skits, TV Patrol excerpts, Theater scenes and SOCO rolled into one
They didn't know what to tell and how to tell it, so they showed a bit of every other thing
They just combined all their scenes by inserting "chapters" and "long texts" in between that literally summarizes what they want to tell-which defeats the purpose of a movie
Some scenes give the impression of one long continuous shot
It actually works when Cristine Reyes is in the scene
Si Cristine Reyes ang nagdala ng pelikula
Tumataas ang tensyon kapag siya na ang nasa eksena
Magaling umiyak si Ella Cruz
Masaya ang tambalan nila Karla Estrada, Elizabeth Oropesa at Beverly Salviejo
Walang dating si Cesar Montano
Walang emosyon si Diego Loyzaga
Walang ginawa sina Kiko Estrada at Kyle Velino
Mas malakas ang prisensya nina Robin Padilla at Giselle Sanchez kahit ilang segundo lang sila nagpakita
Hindi marunong umarte si Ruffa Gutierrez
Lumuluha na pero mukhang nagpapatawa pa rin
Mas magaling pa umarte yung bodyguard na taga-Ilocos daw
Meron mga salita na hindi naman ginagamit nuon
Pero lantaran nilang sinasabi sa pelikulang ito
The scoring is deceiving, trying to enhance the scene-even when there's nothing remarkable in it
Then by the end, there's a sudden tribute to characters that were not given its decent exposure during the actual movie runtime
An illusion that something is made for them-when it is not
Mapanlinlang ang pelikula
Makalat ang kabuuan
Pero hinding hindi ka makakatulog
Gising ka sa lahat ng kaganapan
Katulong ka sa paghubog ng kasaysayan

: This side of the story had long been suppressed to be unraveled to the Filipino people since time immemorial
This mysterious side had always been depicted as the darkest and people in control of information, breeds a notion that it's a damnation to have knowledge about this side

In fact, Philippine history books instill very negative pictures about a past President, while numerous living grandparents and ordinary folks who were witnesses of his reign (including my father, uncles and aunts) were all praises and admiration, calling him the "Best Philippine President ever" were undocumented
This movie stirs additional curiosity to every Filipino as the story revolves from the point-of-view of the first family, being revealed and heard of for the first time
A very family-oriented and brilliant movie you shouldn't miss
As we are intelligent beings, it is but normal to be flipping both sides of the coin
It is a man's liberation and a test of humanity to have knowledge in all sides then decide his subjective judgment which side to believe in
Trash: This a movie meant to distort studied historical accounts and provoke people in a negative way

NO HISTORICAL REVISIONISM: I attended a special screening organized by the 31 Million Movement from Facebook last August 5th held at Greenbelt 3 in Makati
Even it's too far from my house, I rode an Angkas taxi even with torrential rain since I was so late and got all wet, because I know that it will be all worth it
And it did
No disappointments nor any dissatisfaction
I even met Billy Jake Cortez and Julinana Parizcova Segovia, special guests for this screening

Don't mind the 1star reviews: First of all, don't even waste your time reading all the 1-star reviews that were given to this movie
They are just mad because they are driven by the fear that their narratives might be overshadowed
Second of all, this is just a FAMILY drama and intended to show their side of the story that other people outside the President's residence are not aware of
Plot: This is just a straightforward dramedy that tells the struggles of the first family of the Philippines during their last 72 hours inside the Malacañang palace
The movie is divided by chapters
Of course it touched politics, but more than that it was a Family drama
The story was told with a mix of truth and artistic view
The movie will make you cry and laugh at the same time
Tone: It was made to entertain and educate as well
It highlights what is obvious in Politics; trust, betrayal, loyalty, etc
Most importantly, it really tackles the importance of family during difficult times
Acting and Characters: All the actors have played their roles really well
It seems that each character's attitude and behavior fit the actor who played it

Disappointed: Coming into this movie as an excited history buff that wants to see facts and stories from another side, i just came disappointed with the terrible fact checking a supposed history film has made
Not just that
The acting, cinematography and overall performance of the crew and writing of script is very boring
Title doesn't fit with the supposed narrative: I expected to see what was just happening with the family 72 hours before they got exiled

Like a documentary of sorts, what they did, how much they were forced to leave behind

"Huling tatlong araw ng mga Marcos sa Malacañang, ano ang nangyari

" was the supposed plot

Yet, the movie didn't give the experience of a family in their last 72 hours

The progression of events is anti-climactic

The flow of conversation is hollow

The choice of words contribute to the hollowness

The storytelling is disorderly

Continuously changes format narratives

I think if they stuck to a "documentary" type of movie it would've fit well

They didn't know what to tell and how to tell it, so it became an amalgamation of every movie format possible

They just combined all their scenes by inserting "chapters" and "long texts" in between that literally summarizes what they want to tell-which defeats the purpose of a movie

Cristine Reyes carried the movie, Ella Cruz has solid crying acts

Cesar Montano, playing the infamous dictator, has no semblance of the supposed 'strongman' traits of the one he's playing Diego Loyzaga literally has no emotion

Others didn't do anything Looking at you Kiko Estrada

Misrepresentation of nuns with Giselle Sanchez playing mahjong already crosses this film out as a supposed "addition" to history, since said nuns are cloistered

Usage of words that were not present those days, but are yet frequently heard in the movie

Usage of musical scores are way off, since most of the scores play in scenes that are unremarkable

Then by the end, there's a weird and sudden tribute to characters that were not given its decent exposure during the actual movie runtime

An illusion that something is made for them - yet the movie is portraying a supposed tribute for the said dynasty

In the end, you'd stay awake because it isn't boring, but you're trying to understand why the movie is made as it is, and the supposed plot and the actual output strayed so far

A film about a powerful political family facing the reality of their collapse
: The film portrayed the last three days leading to the fall of the Marcos family and their exile to Hawaii in 1986

Taking away the political bias, the context of the film was about how each family member responded and acted to the realization that their world, their paradigm, was about to shatter because of betrayal which is a universal theme that everyone can relate to
The cinematography was good, limited by the fact that the film had a meager budget and there was only one or two shooting locations for the movie
The soundtrack was well-thought of and laid out very well throughout the movie
Editing was better than most Filipino films that I personally had seen

The acting was top-notch, and this is coming from a non-viewer of Filipino films---the performances were riveting and heart-wrenching which took me by surprise and disarmed me which is probably because so many people had given the movie bad reviews based on the trailer and not actually watching it
There were scenes which were jarring to paranoia tempered by scenes that were light-hearted and cringingly humorous
My only wish was that the costumes, props, and settings were more historically accurate, but I will cut it some slack since there wasn't much of a budget to begin with
I would gladly recommend this movie to everybody, and would like to encourage everyone to have an open mind and the suspension of disbelief when going in the movie theatre
One's politics is only a small fraction of one's personality, so leave it at the doorstep and enjoy a rollercoaster ride
This movie is a good one to take the time to watch

by force, as the Philippines had enough of their atrocities, corrupt administration and the poverty they left the country with due to their incapacity to lead the country to progress

SINO BA SILA
: It is not my habit to watch films on the first day they're shown in theaters
Knowing "Maid in Malacañang" is viral, popular, and controversial, I knew the cinemas would be packed so I did not make it an exception
I watched it on the second day yet the theater was still full
This movie is about a family that Filipinos are used to see on TV and read in newspapers and magazines, but never seen and heard behind closed doors
This is the first time to see the candid side of the Marcoses and how they dealt with one of the most tumultuous parts of their regime
The first part had the "Nosi Balasi" playing in the background, which made me think of the critics and the detractors that continue to discredit the Marcoses and their supporters through the years
When you read the lyrics of this song, you'll realize that's exactly how the Marcoses treated their critics in the last 36 years
I knew this film only presents one of the many perspectives of the so-called People Power Revolution in 1986

As the movie progressed, however, it became evident that two main perspectives are being narrated: those of the "maids" or the kasambahays, and that of the other "maid" in Malacanang who promised her father to tell their story in due time: Imee Marcos

Others may disagree with me on this but I see this film more as Imee's perspective of events as the "panganay" and as the unpaid "maid" in Malacanang, who did her best to give order to chaos and make some of the important decisions for her family during the last 72 hours of her father's regime
Having watched so many of Imee's vlogs and interviews, I can only imagine what she was like behind closed doors
It was Christine Reyes' portrayal of the character that gives glimpses of Imee's younger self in a way that I believed she was Imee
Christine showed Imee's facets convincingly: she was feisty, a quick thinker, always on her toes, decisive, a multi-tasker, and at times appeared to be a control freak
The stories of the helpers inside the palace gave me a roller coaster of emotions; but more importantly, they gave the audience an idea of how the Marcoses treated their workers
The fact that the maids could be candid around the president, the first lady, and their children speaks volumes
They also had accounts that painted the Marcoses as "just like other good employers"
One important bit that got me was when the maids showed their furs given by Imelda
The former First Lady told them that they, too, deserved to own furs
This reminded me of what FEM and Imelda often talk about in their writings and interviews: to give dignity to the Filipino people
Of course, I couldn't help but mentally "fact-check" and compare some information in the movie with what I read from books and other publications throughout the campaign period

The part about mainstream media spreading fake news that the Marcoses had already left Malacanang when they were still in the palace can be found in Paul Goldstein's article in EIR Journal dated July 25, 1986
There was also the bit about Cory winning the elections based on NAMFREL's tally and FEM winning based on COMELEC's tally
You can find this info in Cecilio Arillo's book, A Country Imperiled and Rigoberto Tiglao's book, Debunked

The part where the people at EDSA headed to Radio Veritas can be found in Paul Goldstein's article in EIR dated July 15, 1986

There's also something I noticed that's unique in this film that I don't see often in other Filipino films: the art of long takes
A "long take" is a shot that's intended to appear as a single, uninterrupted take in the final edit of a film
I thought this was interesting as it made the scenes appear more intimate
Long takes can draw you closer to the scene
At times, I felt transported into the story as if I were there in the moment with the characters, but as a silent and invisible observer
As the camera gracefully glided from one angle to another, the drama and tension became more palpable
That's because long takes mimic the real-life scenarios of freely moving through space and time while expressing feelings of agony, confusion, and fear
I jokingly posted yesterday on Facebook: "Who wrote the screenplay, Direk
Because it was attempting to make me cry

"

And I did cry an ugly cry
Darryl, you're a brilliant writer
I felt the suffering, the confusion, the hopelessness, and the shattering of the souls of the characters
The simplest of lines can turn those who are hardened into misty-eyed
You will identify something very personal in your own life with a line, a scene, a character, or a moment in this movie
I am not sure anyone could have written the screenplay any better as you did

Another thing that I liked about this film is there were almost no actions and no special effects -- just a family and their staff talking to one another sometimes in a group, sometimes just between two people or among the family members
It's the simplicity of it that highlights its sentimental edge with dialogues so movingly performed
You'll probably never find the stories of these characters in any publications mainly because they chose to remain quiet for decades or maybe they were not given the chance to air their side

While others will most likely question the accuracy of the narratives in this film, no one should invalidate them especially when these perspectives come from characters who LIVED inside Malacanang for several years
Like I said several times in my previous posts, there are hundreds or even thousands of ways to narrate an event depending on who is telling it
Maid in Malacañang is about the perspectives of those inside the palace at the time when the opposition and the people on EDSA also crafted their own stories to tell

All perspectives are valid, especially of those who were in the same rooms as the president of the Republic These perspectives are pieces that help complete a puzzle that perplexed the nation for decades
The movie did not negate exiting perspectives at all
In fact, perspectives should be looked at and treated separately without prejudice against one another
This is how we understand both sides objectively
This is how we form a more complete picture of an important event in our history
Maid in Malacañang is about how it makes you feel in the end
This movie makes me feel hopeful as a Filipino because, perhaps, this can help pave the way to national reconciliation so we can finally move on together as one
We are entitled to know the TRUTH

After military and rebel forces in collusion with the USA and the Catholic Church in the Philippines stole the 1986 snap elections from the democratically elected president, the late Ferdinand E
Marcos, rioters, looters and criminals stormed Malacañang Palace
Darkness swept across the land as a Yellow dictator illegally took over the government
This was the start of the decline of our country's fortunes
Infrastructure, culture and the arts, agriculture, technology and even education gradually deteriorated due to her government's incompetence and corruption
The departure of the Marcoses signaled the start of our national trials and tribulation
History is not through with the Marcoses
The story of our country's success, security and prosperity begins again
Two great families - powerhouses, polar opposites and legacies - have come, a son of the North and a daughter of the South
Together, they are electrifying the world with their statecraft
What a glorious time to be alive, to be a Filipino
Philippine history is upended
The truth and lies which were deviously but masterfully mangled, marbled and warped through the passage of time are now under scrutiny
This is a reckoning
We are fighting not just for our stories today but for everyday that we have lost since the historical revision which began in 1986
The past - hidden by the hate-filled lies of the academics, the clergy and the media - are finally seeing the Philippine sunrise for the first time
Let it not be dimmed and cowed into obscurity again

An Actual Objective Review of the Movie: Okay
I am writing this because I just watched it earlier
First of all, folks, the movie is not "bad"
You only deem it bad because it portrays the side of the Marcoses
Second, Have you watched it
Have you actually bought tickets to see the film
If yes, did you watch it for entertainment
Or did you watch it as your source for "the truth"
Because if you went for the latter, then you're a snowflake and you just proved the other party's point that they can trigger you
Your source of information shouldn't be on what you see on the movies
It's a movie, give everyone a break
Third, they portrayed the side of the Marcoses
If you think your idea of their own experiences should be followed, then you go make and produce the movie
Fourth, when did you actually see a Marcos film post 1986
You know, the one that depicts their part of the story, even if it was bad
Was there
Honest question
Because I don't think there ever was
And this was the perfect film for it
Admit it or not, post 1986 we were already bombarded with Anti-Marcos, Pro Aquino, NPA, Martial Law events and victims movies - BUT
Anyway, here is my take on the movie
First five-ish "Chapters" of the movie went on with no cut scenes
I found this amazing as it shows their mastery of their script and their character
The build up of the story was slow but entertaining, nonetheless, thanks to the comic of the three maids

They were obviously pointing out references to defend themselves (Marcoses) which was kind of a smirking moment for me - it wasnt because I doubt them or something but more of a "Okay they are being defensive on this part but go on

"

The team tried to build up the story by "Chaptering" the whole plot which is I think is kind of in the infant stage of Philippine cinema, at least they tried, and I should give credit to them because it was in a unique way of directing/producing the film
Given the fact that our movie industry is falling apart because of the likes of mainstream tweetums drama cliche stories of Cardo Dalisay, Kim Chiu, Vice Ganda and the like
Feels of the movie could be better
I guess it was just the filter of the picture
There were scenes of some of news cuts
It was okay for references but again, it could be portrayed/edited better
But nevertheless, the cinematic feels is there
The torches, the Mahjong, the nuns were better off omitted if possible
But it is their point of view so whether or not these were true, they left it for us to do more research if we wanted confirmation
Acting: The three maids, were great especially Beverly Salviejo
Great Character
Ella Cruz was really into it
I thought she's just one of those actresses who was just famous
But no, she can act
And she can perform really well
Cesar Montano as always has always been a great actor
So thats just it
Diego Loyzaga needs improvement
I can't wait for his lines to be finished
Ruffa depicted Imelda just fine
Nothing much engagement with the film
Finally, Christine Reyes
She went on full beast mode with this one
The acting was just overflowing but I guess that how they wanted to portray her
Overall, come on guys
It's a film so just watch it
Be objective enough to give where proper credit is due and not just because of Historical Revisionism point of view
It gets old
Compare him to Hitler for all I care, but some of you watched Davinci Code, Hitler movies and Lucifer the TV show
I mean, come on
Will watch Katips tomorrow and will leave a reply to that review as well

My child's POV (History taught on their school): As a parent born in 1980, I want my children to have their freedom of expression and we respect it because it is their rights

We watched it on the first day of the movie (Aug 3, 2022) so that we can experience the vibe of millions of Filipinos who are hunger for entertainment and excited to go out with their families after 2 years of fear, anxiety brought by pandemic
The movie MiM is a very family oriented movie, that's why it has a rating of PG
And we can assure that it is very understandable and remarkable in the minds of our little ones
Me and my husband together with my youngest (15yr old), really enjoyed our family time - we laugh, react and even hide our little tears while watching the movie

It really touched our hearts as a FATHER to his SON, a SON to his FATHER & MOTHER, a DAUGHTER to her FATHER, and an AMO to their KASAMBAHAYS, we don't even thought of any political motives and it doesn't enter our minds that it was a black propaganda againts the previous administrations after the Marcos regime
I am not a movie expert, but I have eyes to see what is beautiful or not, I have hands that can feel the hands of my child that touched me during scenes that might get her nervous or excited
And I have a heart that can feel the hurt, the fear, and the hopelessness of a family that was betrayed by their so-called friends, allies, supporters and even families
I can relate to that, because I even experienced that in real life
When we got home, I asked my child "so anak may nabago ba sa history nyo
" She said "wala naman po mommy"
And that's from my child's point of view
And that's their freedom
Congrats to the writer and director Darryl Yap
The truth will set us free

Admittedly, I have a love hate relationship with Darryl Yap's movies
Don't like Pornstar 2, Babaeng Walang Pakiramdam, Revirginized
Indifferent to Gluta, liked Pornstar, liked Jowable alot and truly AMAZED at Tililing
(All of which we have posts of as well) Had high hopes with this one but I really didn't know what to expect
The story telling part was very well done
Same with the choice of music and scoring
Could have been so flat and boring because it was mostly talking among a few, emphasis on a few characters on a single location with a single topic
BUT, Biday, took control of this movie

There were a lot of powerful scenes and her involvement in those scenes, though actually minor and irrelevant and some made just to lighten the mood was SO ON POINT and FUNNY it made this movie that much more fun to watch
Truly unexpected and caught me off guard that made me laugh so hard
The cast in general were really good, special mention to Christine Reyes, wow, Cesar Montano, wow, and BEVERLY SALVIEJO, WOW
Ella Cruz had one powerful great scene and hoped she did more
8 of 10 for me
Was suppose to be a 9 but that cheap shot in the end was distasteful and merits a minus one, even if the telephone conversation (alone) was based on a documented interview
BUT, overall, something worth watching, specially because of Biday :D #wherecollectingisalifestyle

IT'S NOT REALLY AN HISTORICAL DISTORTION NOR A BIOPIC, IT'S JUST ALL ABOUT THE LAST DAYS OF THE MARCOSES IN MALACAÑANG DURING 1986 EDSA REVOLUTION: At first, we really thought or expect that it was historical distortion or revisionism of what really happened during the 1986 EDSA People Power Revolution
But we've surprised and dissapointed, disappointed because we thought there will be revisionism but they did not have that
And here's my review about the movie, which is same as the reviews of Mr
Mark Perez Agullana
The movie as the trailer suggested it is about the few days of The Marcoses in Malacañan Palace from the personal account of their household helper or maid and the Maid in Malacañan Senator Imee R
By watching this movie, it presented a view I rarely see, read or hear about the Marcoses
Of course, it touched politics but more than that it was a family drama, the other side of the villain most of us do not know through the eyes of those close to him
The story was told with mix of "truth" and "artistic license"
It was fun, laughters and tears
The story was told in a clear simple manner that everyone can easily follow
Themes and Tone The main theme of the movie for me is family than politics
It was made to entertain and educate as well
It is easy to spot on the funny and entertaining jokes inserted in the movie

It is also highlighting and presenting what are the obvious in politics and life - traitorship, allyship, trust, honesty, doing what is right, doing what is good, family connection, friendship and other values
But most importantly, it highlighted the most important unit of the society, the family and its importance especially in difficult times
It tells the importance of making up a decision and acting on it
There are many symbolisms in the film like the conversation between Bonget and Imelda and how they will be able to return to the Philippines and to the power, great use of imagination
And of course, the most controversial scene of Cory played by Giselle Sanchez

That closing scene and the statement are great show of how Politics and Religion are playing the lives of many Filipinos, the fate of the nation and its wealth while they are lucky for having a seat of power
Until today this is true, in every election and important bills being pushed in the congress
Acting and Characters I like how each character played their roles
Still, Cesar Montano is Cesar Montano
From Muro Ami to this film
I am thinking how difficult it maybe for Diego Loyzaga to act with his father
Great scene
I wish I have a conversation with my father on important matters in my life
I feel like ILoveRuffaG is not Ruffa with her like x100 very slow movement in the movie
But I like how she potrayed Imelda with so much grace, beauty and elegance
She is really different from who she really is
She matched and gave justice to the role
Ella Cruz is okay
Not too much, not less
But she really did great in her scene with Cesar convincing the father to move out
The three maids were really good
Karla Estrada and Beverly Salviejo were very funny in their scene which gave a balance to this dramatic movie
It was not OA
Of course, Christine Reyes who played the very important role, showed in the movie the acting you expect from her
Direction Daryll Yap's signature story telling was very evident in the movie
It was simple, not complicated, not too fast and not to slow directing
It was almost a straightforward story telling with symbolisms in a funny way
There was a little tension
Score The music chosen for each scene were matched perfectly to build the emotions and connect to the characters and story
I like the song choice
Cinematography The camera movement especially during long walks of Imee is bit shaky, maybe budget or I am not certain if that was intentional
The various shots and angle were good
It is comparable to mainstream films at low budget
I like how the camera was moving in circular motion changing the position of the characters of Bonget and Imelda while they were talking
It depicted how their lives were turning up side down
The lines, the shot, the movement and acting were aligned
All actors were framed properly
Production Design The costumes and props were good
They matched with the story, the setting and the characters
Special Effects There's not much special effects used in the movie except the sound effects which are okay
Editing The film was cleanly edited
The flow is consistent
The transitions used are very simple but effective alongside with the effects and music
Pace The pace is neither slow nor fast
It was enough
Each scene is not dragging and arranged properly
It was like small episodes of the usual vincentiments film and combined as one
Dialogue There are conversations that I really feel not needed and the movie will stand still
Oh well, there is really a good script
Lessons There are many lessons you can take from the movie
It presented an alternative view of the existing truth about the freedom we are enjoying today
Does it change the way I view EDSA, Cory, FEM, Ramos, Juan Ponce Enrile, the Nuns, the Martial Law victims, the truth, the democracy and others

It just reaffirmed what I am already believing about FEM, Cory, Ramos, Johnny, the Marcos Family, the Aquino Family, the Nuns, the Martial Law Victims, the EDSA Rallyists and the Filipino People - they are all human beings neither good nor bad
That good or bad outcomes are based from each person's decisions and actions
The movie was good, but I expect more next time
Indeed, the crowd went applauded after watching the movie
I just want to understand those person who are full of hatred in this movie even the truth is always truth
And this kind of movie, was made from the creative minds and imaginations
Their situations are believable, but the drama or act
Hehehe only they know the truth
Little spoiler: The Mahjong scene does have POWERFUL MESSAGE
MUST WATCH

: I'd say 99% of the low rating reviews that the movie received came from people who have not watched the movie, I'll tell you why after I share my honest and objective review of the one of the most popular and controversial Filipino movies of 2022
Most of these people are saying the movie twisted the usual narrative and that it revised the history by peddling lies about the Marcoses

The person who'd say just that is being too dramatic and is most likely a god who's all knowing of what actually happened inside the house and the minds of the Marcoses during the last 72 hours of its dynasty
No one can really tell you what exactly happened in the last 72 hours as every person's perception of an event that took place in the past has his/her own version of that event
Say you interview 10 people from a single event, each one of those participants may have different version based on his/her perception, views, and beliefs
Hence, you can't say someone else's testimony or version of an event is "false" or "wrong"
There is no absolute right or wrong - what's right for you may not be right for others, do not be all too self righteous

However, this movie in particular is truly controversial as the movie apparently did not put the Marcoses in the bad light, which is something new to most people given how this last name is notorious for being the worst of the worst kinds of people - only if social media existed during the Marcos dynasty, back then, it was easy for powerful people to twist the minds and realities of the masses
The theater in Cebu (SM Seaside) where I watched was i'd say was about 95% full, and the movie received a round of applause upon reaching the credits
If that doesn't make a movie good for you, then I do not know what is
Again, what's a good movie for you may not be good for the others viewers, and that's alright
As always, watch the movie before you rate it

The movie is not an "attempt" to "revise history" or to "distort" it
The movie is simply a glimpse of how the Marcoses handled their situation inside Malacanang Palace as EDSA "people power" was going on outside their gate
It's how they struggled through the ordeal individually as a son/daughter, as a father, as a mother, as member of the extended family (the maids), and how they handled it as a family as well
Sure there were scenes that can be thought of as provocative
They can be seen as a swipe to Cory and those who masterminded and staged PP but they were very few and far in between
Besides, the movie itself caters to a specific audience
It's for those who are sympathetic to the Marcoses so it's to be expected that it will play to its audience
Anyway, this is more of a family drama more than anything else
It humanized the Marcoses
And it was done in a way that it did
not completely absolved them nor completely glorified them
Honestly, I don't know where the fear is coming from
Anyway, it's refreshing to see a Filipino movie that is different from the usual
This film can pioneer a revolution in the industry

This movie used a lot of symbolism, there are character development even within that short span of time
ive not seen this done in most of our movies

A very interesting film: I came in thinking there would have been a "history revisionism" because it was what most talked about but I was pleasantly surprised to see that it was not the case
It was merely showing things, as they unfold, through the eyes of the accused

This movie opens up a lot of things for discussion and further examination
History, the same with any scientific claim, must react and change according to new evidence discovered, submitted or unearthed
I really think people should stop judging the film before they get a chance to watch it
They should also keep an open mind and let their curiousity be piqued

Worth the watch - For open-minded viewers: It's a family drama with an excellent pinch of comic relief
Contrary to the "hate" it's getting from those who have not really watched it due to political leaning, this movie did deliver on entertainment value
The actors performed surprisingly well
From the extras, "maids" and to the lead roles, kudos
Story telling was smooth and editing was masterfully stitched
Soundtrack, hands down
The director really made an effort to tell the story without pretense
It was raw
Was there a historical revisionism
I didn't think so
My father had personal accounts of the ML and the story was already ingrained in me since childhood
So I think, (at least to my perspective) that this story was something else
In the cinema, I do hear people being emotional from some scenes
Seeing some audience nearby my seat, trying to wipe their tears
I was also one of those
I was actually moved not because of the characters itself but on how the director and the actors made the story relatable to common people - family
It does make you realize how important it is to learn from experiences and that it's always wise to listen to your parents
Love - is the primordial factor of survival
If some people wouldn't think about the baggage of what this movie is all about, then I think it deserve better scores

Owh,way back 1986, EDSA people power took place and as a result,the Marcos family and the late President Ferdinand Marcos have nothing to do but to stepback and surrender the presidency

Sell the biggest government owned electricity establishment to private,change the Manila International Airport to her late husband's name, confiscating and freezing all the Marcos wealth, file hundreds or thousand of cases about the family which in Hawaii,the time wherein Ferdinand Marcos is already dying

Emotion-triggering, tears and laughter: Despite all the fuss about this film, I went to watch it with an open mind
It could go either way but it did not disappoint
I liked that the movie was broken down into chapters
I liked the dynamic of the family, it's just like a normal family who goes through traumatic events
I mean, how is it not traumatic when there are so many death threats
The pacing is easy to digest, I love the details that were of the era
The biggest take away I have is that, not everything is as media portrays it
Which is very rampant even to this date
It only solidifies all the stories I heard from my 79 year old father who lived and thrived
He always shared stories of life back in the day
The narrative over the past 34 years have been the same, it's old and tired
The narrative has been broken
I think it's high time to hear the other side, which is weird because there are a few who are against it
Even during a trial, there's prosecution and defense
We werent allowed to hear the defense side of things, it's due time to hear the other side
Also, if those years were truly the worst of the times, how come some of the very crucial hospitals that were made then are still very useful these days
What's even more boggling is that those who wished to overthrow then president and promised better lives for Filipinos did the exact opposite of what they promised the people
How come instead of making our lives better it became stagnant and even went downhill
Where is the improvement they promised
Heart center, lung center, and kidney institute were not improved and there werent any creation of additional public hospitals like those anymore
Those facilities that were built in that "dark era" are still functional to this date
Overrun as they are, they help the common citizen
These are some of the things that broke the opposing narrative
We refuse to be led to believe the holier-than-thou narrative
It's overused and tired
The hypocrisy is blatant and we no longer stand beside it
The movie showcases amazing acting from very good artists, it'll trigger so many emotions in the audience no matter your age or sex
At the end of the day, it is an imagining of the last 72 hours in Malacañang in 1986
It is a movie, democracy is for everyone not for a select few
This movie should be watched those who bash it have an alternate agenda and it's petty

I Didn't Like It But Definitely Entertaining: So what are my thoughts about Maid In Malacañang
This is a non paid review for this film
Unlike trolls who reviewed this film and gave this bad marks without watching it
So to start
I don't like it
But read along before you attack with torches and hurl insults
Here are reasons why

(Warning : Few Spoilers)

This is not a historical movie
If you want to see something stronger, then watch Brocka's banned movie or actual news footage
Not a movie told from the perspective of the producer, the director or the award giving bodies
If you are expecting a revisionist movie like dispelling rumours about the Marcoses excesses and opulence, this is not for you

It doesn't hide their wealth and their control of people around them - from the luxury-wearing zero-gravity moving Imelda, to the scary bossy angered Imee, the party going camou-wearing brave-wanting Bonget
No sugar coating here - they are revealed as spoiled people
It doesn't portray the Marcoses as the bravest souls as they show here how they spiraled to their fears and frustrations, the latter shown by former President FEM himself

If you are expecting them to be portrayed here as a blameless hero family, they aren't as even Irene

It doesn't show the Marcoses as the most powerful family in the country as they too failed to save their entire extended household (meaning those who lived long with them in the palace)
The mahjong scene that irked many before the actual showing revealed the figures who were more powerful, and I emphasize, were as it is passe
And it is not the one who sat at the mahjong table but the bigger entity some tried to represent mockingly
It didn't show the atrocities during Martial Law nor it depicted further the evil side of many politicians some have come to worship for decades
Nor did it tackle the roots of what made Martial Law to be declared
It didn't utilise more some actors like Elizabeth Oropesa, the controversial Ella Cruz and even the most hated actress now for portraying the symbolic yellow wearing saint, Gieselle Sanchez
I feel like some scenes really got stolen much by the superb timing and acting of Beverly Salviejo aka Manang Biday
But it did reveal some things that would make more people ponder, especially with the "what ifs"
Highly entertaining as was the movie, I am left with questions after seeing it as the pieces still don't feel complete

With many puzzle pieces hidden before like actual video clips of how the palace was stormed and yes, burned (as there are actual reports to such in the news), the actual announcements to join EDSA uprising (I wish they put recordings of those actual announcements of Sin calling the faithful), to the big reveal for some that Marcoses were aimed to be killed by friends and some organised people, I can't help but ponder is the running time enough for film or is this better a series
Some things are made clear here though
First, and I won't be apologetic
This is a middle finger movie to Ramos who died days before the movie was shown
Maybe he chose to die before his humiliation can be revealed that he was indeed part of planners to kill off the first family
I know BBM paid respects but the Maid in Malacañang didn't and I understand her for that
This is also a big middle finger movie to family and friends who betray us for politics
Darryl never shies away from controversy and arguments
With the 2022 election campaign being hailed as the most toxic we experienced (and maybe the worst of all time)
The lines hit hard that you eat on the same plate with people who wish you dead
Sadly, toxicity is shared on the plate
This is not a hate film though
In fact, it is a beautifully crafted melodrama with light touches of humor and reference to 80s, to telenovelas and even PRRD's expletives
The music was superb, the pacing mostly on point but always easy to follow and the acting delivered credibly by everyone in the main cast
If Cesar Montano and Beverly Salviejo don't get awards here, we know some directors probably thought to award it to someone else and found their own reflections
Darryl also is masterful in creating memorable lines like how he delivered with his notoriously popular LenLen series
My dad kept repeating some of the lines he remembered and I of course love villains so you know whose I remember the most
Add the symbolisms, references and mild swearing he put may look or sound cliche for some but those are reminders that this movie is not perfect nor the people shown in it

It doesn't lie like others hailing their own as absolute truth and true masterpiece that must be seen again (and I say again as not much watched the first run, it wouldn't earn either with a re-run if not put side by side with Maid in Malacañang)
It doesn't lie that it is not without creative liberties meant to stir emotions at almost every chapter as they hit the right nerves at most points
Maid in Malacañang is not a movie made to justify lies as others claim it would be
Rather, it presents itself as a vulnerable piece prone to dissection - hence chapters
It is highly entertaining as it is thought provoking, tear inducing, BP raising, heart warming
So I don't like it
I love it

PS the final mahjong scene looks funny in the trailers but it is actually a sinister dark energy filled take, from the daunting music which reminds of The Omen, to the evil spewed out lines to the closing of hands playing with yellows
A promotion of what was to come
Darryl should make a horror film continuation about this

I hosted a private screening of #MIM last 9 August
I carefully selected the audience ensuring a generational mix

There are six (6) generations: Baby Boomers: born 1946 to 1964; Generation Jones: born 1955 to 1965; Generation X: born1 965 to 1980; Xennials: born 1977 to 1983; Millennials: born 1981 to 1996; Generation Z: born 1997 or after and Generation Alpha: born 2010 or after
Only Generation Alpha was not represented
A total of 56 individuals watched #MIM
There was no revisionism made
It provided the 72 hours on the other side of the proverbial fence, the side of the Marcoses which were never really made clear to all Filipinos
The side I hated and never crossed in my youthful years
But a leader I knew from grade school to college
He was my only president for my first 23 years
Of course I didn't know the POV of the three (3) maids but certainly knew of Sen
Imee Marcos' role as "mayordoma" - she was after all the assistant of her father, being the eldest and more knowledgeable than the other siblings
MiM reinforced the characterizations I learned of Imee Marcos and Bongbong Marcos growing up
There was no sugarcoating on those two
What got my attention was that of the youngest, Irene Marcos
She was never political
She was always the sweet girl with a ready smile
That scene of Irene Marcos with the father was gut wrenching
Was there creative license there
I don't know because Irene Marcos has never been in the public eye
But that scene summed up what to be in government meant, what to hold power and how to deal with people wanting more
Meron bang mabuting pamahalaan is still ringing
Clearly the sibling rivalry was there
Clearly, Imee was her father's daughter and Bongbong was the mama's boy
On point was a strong Imee and a gentle and low-key Bongbong
The moorings of the son was palpable in the scenes with the eldest, father and mother
Interesting that the journal page on Bongbong had an extended play with FM saying he believed in his son despite being a spoiled brat, the son after all was out to secure the support of the father
In politics, the namesake will always have that internal doubt (am I worthy of the name
Can I be better than my father
Could I achieve even just an inch of what he has done
I have seen that internal debates with fathers and sons in the world of politics
The scene of loyalists remaining in the palace wearing yellow and doing the L sign were just stories I heard from friends who joined the march to Malacanang on that night
"May mga tao kaming nadatnan pero pro-Aquino
" I remembered the trashing, the bringing out of souvenirs
I myself had a piece of the barbed wire but can't recall where it is today
Ang "kasaysayan ay chismis"
Puede pero sa ilang dekadang pagsasaliksik at paghahanap ng katotohanan, puede and chismis ay nagkakaruon ng ugat at yumayabong hanggat may nagiibang daloy para ito muling baguhin
Hindi natutulog ang kasaysayan
Ito ay umiikot kung may kontrang daluyan ng punto o pangyayari na uusig sa ating kinagisnan
Darryl Yap knows the public pulse so well
He intertwined happy and sad; comedic relief in a hot confrontation; the power of the moment and the internal questions one get to ask about how to love a country are all in the film
Sometimes, its takes a very ordinary view by maids that we discover the real narrative at the back of certain events
They may not sit well for some but it has to be told
Were the Marcoses placed in a different light after MiM
Yes, because we saw their humanity and no, because the final chapter has yet to be written
As a wise man said to me after the film, it would be better to see who instigated all these things
"Where is Joma in all these

"

MiM also confirmed the role of a foreign power in getting the Marcoses out
They were escorted and just by a call, they were rerouted
I again remember a favorite adage: "In politics, nothing happens by accident
If it does, you can bet it was planned that way

"

Actors portrayal of Marcos family and all the cast were superb, intriguing, miraculous and very funny
It is not a film about pro or anti Marcos, it's about simple things in life which is love to humanity
In terms of its technical aspect, I was blown away from the costumes, props
( airplane was one of them), and the soundtrack was top notch, you'll be humming it after you saw it, a world class classic
Bring a napkin or tissue, the theater will be filled with tears

SUPER BLOCK BUSTER FILIPINO MOVIE OF THE YEAR AFTER PANDEMIC: THE EMPEROR'S SWINDLER: A SPOILER-FREE REVIEW OF DARRYL YAP'S MAID IN MALACAÑANG BY SASS ROGANDO SASSOT

I have watched Darry Yap's other films - Jowables, Pornstar series, and Revirginized
What I noticed in those films is Yap's storytelling: he begins strong, then somewhere in the story he rushes to reach a denouement
Maid in Malacañang (MiM) is a different Yap
Nothing felt rushed, the storytelling progressed like an onion being peeled delicately
Yap peeled MiM so delicately in its intricate layers, letting the audience shed tears as each layer unravelled, without emotionally manipulating them to do so
And like in his other films, Yap combined drama and comedy - this time, seamlessly
There's still the usual preachy parts, like in his other films - this time, integrated so well as a narrative device, rather than as a cop out from the labor of story development
As an ensemble, the cast is skilfully selected
Cesar Montano is a Bernini sculpture: the minutest detail of his acting is Ferdinand E
Diego Loyzaga is spot on in his portrayal of President BBM's coming of age moment
Real-life father and son, Cesar and Diego's confrontation scene is like watching a masterclass in acting
Ruffa Guttierez's elegant acting unveiled Imelda, as a mother, beneath all the glamor
Ella Cruz as Irene Marcos tells us she has a bright future in Philippine cinema
The three maids: Karla Estrada's comedic timing is masterfully delivered
Elizabeth Oropesa is timeless
Even when she's just standing, she makes you believe
Beverly Salviejo deserves a standing ovation for every scene: Give her her own full-length film
One never wastes a juggernaut like her
Even if there are 24 characters in a film, just cast Salviejo, and she would be able to persuade you that there were 24 different actors
Cristine Reyes as Imee Marcos
She does not deserve an acting award
Reyes must be given a monument
Rename NAIA, EDSA, the West Philippine Sea after her -- I don't care
Reyes, like Montano, is a Bernini sculpture: even when she is deep in thought, she is giving us Imee Marcos
If Reyes could top her acting prowess in MiM, name an entire galaxy after her
As the film reached its denouement, I cursed: "Potaena ka Darryl Yap
Brilliantly wicked

"

The Emperor's New Clothes told the story of the swindlers who made a fool of an emperor and his ministers
They promised to weave the finest cloth for the emperor, and whoever wouldn't be able to see it is unusually stupid
Unusually stupid - that's how enfant terrible Yap made everyone who thinks so highly of themselves looked like with his most brilliant work to date
MiM's real plot isn't in the film itself
This is one of the rare instances where the real plot developed after the film has been promoted publicly
In this sense, MiM is just a subplot
The main plot is the one - consciously or unconsciously - written by Yap: The mass hysteria of people addicted to their victimhood - real or imagined, reacting to the film they never watched
Yap directed a satire -- and it's not MiM

If you're as alert as the innocent child in The Emperor's New Clothes, you will easily spot the nakedness of the Emperor, his ministers who lost the plot, and the swindlers who wove the finest golden cloth worn by history

" I cannot remember this topic being discussed in any history class nor in any "special feature" telenovela nor in any movie at that
Previously made films or dramas always celebrated how the Aquinos were supposedly the heroes of Philippine democracy
No other film in the contemporary time had tackled the story of Maid in Malacanan
And for that alone, I think this is a must watch for every Filipino, whatever political inclination you may have

Its about time to tell to the world

A Surprisingly Good Movie with Roman Catholic Themes: A surprisingly good movie, considering the sensitive subject matter
Genuine characterizations of the Marcos family, including their personality flaws, and a nice balance of drama and humor
Not at all revisionist, as the contents are mainly interpersonal events between the Marcos family and household staff, and TV news footage
Looking forward to the sequel
There are a lot of Christian and Roman Catholic themes in the movie
I will not mention these in my review to avoid spoiling the movie
These themes become more evident on the second or third viewing
Observe the way the characters are presented visually
Also listen carefully to what they say, especially their choice of words
Observe things that are present around the characters
The genre of the movie is definitely political, with the objective of humanizing the Marcos political family
This is good, because the Marcos family are human beings, and the movie is telling this truth
But I think the movie at its core, is deeply Roman Catholic, and uses the story of the Marcos family to communicate spiritual truths
I did not give the movie the highest rating because there are some parts of the movie that "tell you" rather than "show you" through action and character development
But it is not easy to see this because the acting is so good

You are able to lose yourself in the world of the Marcos family during their final days in power, and we also care about the characters so much that we do not clearly discern the screenplay writer "preaching to you"

A lot of criticism about the movie comes from the final scene where Cory Aquino is playing Mahjong with some nuns, as they say this did not happen, and so give this final scene as an example of historical revisionism
However, what Cory was doing at the time is not historically significant
The critics miss what is being communicated in this scene at a spiritual level
Observe closely the altar next to the Mahjong table
Do you notice anything odd
What is the position of Cory Aquino relative to the altar
Do you notice anything odd about the nuns
If you see the spiritual theme being presented, then now you might have something significant to be upset about, after you get over the initial shock
Enjoy the movie
It gets better with every viewing

It is a spoiler review, so I recommend that you watch the movie first

: Having finally watched Maid in Malacanang twice already over the last couple of days, I felt I should take to IMDB myself to rate the movie
Before watching this film, I had no idea really of what it might have actually really been like during those last 72 hours of the Marcos Presidency

It's very easy just to rely on what's out there already in terms of historical documentation and documentaries on the Marcos era and those days as well as the so called EDSA revolution, but what we don't know is what it was really like for those present with the family themselves, what were there feelings, emotional responses and so much more
This movie and that era has been brought to life through the excellent storytelling of Philippine director, Darryl Yap
I believe he has put his heart and soul into this movie as have the whole cast and crew
Both Cesar Montano and Christine Reyes put on great performances, really believable and heartfelt
If I could rate this movie as 11/10 I would
Please do all you can to watch this wonderful masterpiece

true story: The movie is actually a family dramedy
If there is one thing that I find problematic, it is the stereotypical typecasting, once again, of maids becoming the sources of comic relief

But certainly, it is hard not to be amazed by Yap's masterful weaving in of humor as a punchline, most vividly represented by that emotionally charged confrontation between father and son Ferdinand Marcos Sr
And Jr
, played by real father and son Cesar Montano and Diego Loyzaga, capped by the tiptoeing Biday, ably played by veteran comedian Beverly Salviejo

It was seen again in that touching dramatic silent monologue of Imelda Marcos played by Ruffa Gutierrez as she bid goodbye to her material possessions of gowns and shoes, taking only small mementos and love letters her husband Ferdie sent her, to the tune of that iconic 'Dahil Sa Iyo,' which turned out to be not a soundtrack but Biday, again, belting out her own aria as she was dusting a flower vase

On a larger scale, the entire movie was actually a wicked punchline to rudely douse water ON the misplaced fears, the ruckus and the noise, about this movie becoming a monumental sacrilege to the altars of historical purity
There is nothing in this movie that actually distorts, revises, or replaces what we already know

This is not Yap and Viva Films trying to assault history with outlandish claims, but simply a dramatic, and sometimes hilarious, representation of a powerful family at their most vulnerable, most defeated state as they faced their imminent downfall
It is the story of an eldest daughter, a role excellently enacted by Cristine Reyes playing Senator Marcos who struggled to lead a family in the throes of collapse, trying to hold it together
It is the story of a son, poignantly played by Loyzaga as the young President Ferdinand Marcos Jr
, trying to make his father proud, trying to prove that he can be more than the party animal with whom his father expressed disappointment
It is the story of youngest daughter Irene Marcos Araneta played by Ella Cruz pleading with her father, and whose lines in the movie embodied a summary of the entire political career of her father
Some people took note of the absence of any reference to the actual reasons why EDSA took place, and count this as a deficiency of the movie

What they missed is that this movie is less a historical account of EDSA, or the political downfall of the Marcoses, but a family drama to reveal the stories behind the façade of the presidential palace

Ella Cruz's character of Irene summed up what can possibly be said about the rule of her father - that his government was not perfect, and that he lost control of it and his people, many of whom betrayed him
These are factual claims
There is no deliberate attempt to radically alter facts
Instead, what is given space is to provide the Marcos narrative a voice, and for the audience to form their own interpretations
The scene of the stash of cash at the beginning of the movie is perfect imagery that captured this

It establishes the fact that indeed there were boxes full of undistributed cash, which many would interpret as money intended to buy voters in the 1986 snap elections, but the character representing Senator Marcos rationalized it as payment for people who actually worked for the Marcos campaign
It was left to the viewers to form their own conclusions as to which narrative we will believe

The much talked about, and bashed scene, of former president Corazon Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, who incidentally are clearly represented not as the Carmelite sisters, is actually an artistic and symbolic representation, following another symbolic scene where Ferdinand and Imelda waltzed while Malacañang was being attacked by a mob
If there is one moment where Yap made a political commentary, it would be in this symbolic representation of the political elites playing with the Church during EDSA
And no one can dispute that indeed the Church played a crucial role there
This movie is not about revising history but about humanizing the Marcoses at their most vulnerable and weakest
This is something that cannot be denied by anyone, tyrant or otherwise
It doesn't change what they did or failed to do
If there is another important fact that this movie revealed, it is that aside from the Marcoses there were others in Malacañang when it fell
These were the people who served them as guards and maids, who for so long were invisible, but finally were given a voice in this film
In the end, the politics of this film is less seen in its content but more in how it has been received
It is like an RT-PCR test that would reveal whether we are positive with partisan prejudice, or negative and tolerant of other voices

Beverly Salviejo made me laugh
Kudos to Direk Darryl and Viva films for this masterpiece movie we millennials are craving for
Worth Watching: This is a good story from the other side of the spectrum which gives audience a chance to veer away from the long standing narrative of EDSA
Direk Yap did not hide the real truth behind MIM
In fact, he is transparent declaring in a recent interview that, "This is a family in crisis film
" and is to be appreciated from the perspective of the maids, primarily the three Yayas - Biday (Beverly Salviejo), Lucy (Elizabeth Oropesa), and Santa (Karla Estrada)

He also did not conceal the fact that the Marcos family had a direct hand in the making of the film, admitting in the same interview that Senator Imee Marcos deleted some from the original script, added some of her own, and approved the final script
Senator Imee Marcos is also the Executive Producer
It is in these regards that those behind MIM are honest and transparent as to the intentions of the movie
And yeah, the number of ratings gives justice that this movie is indeed worth watching for Filipinos
The last 72 hrs
: If you're expecting a political thriller or a historical biopic, this is not it
While based on true accounts, this is not about flipping the EDSA narrative at all
It is not to glorify the first family nor to make them heroes
So all the fuss about historical revisionism as far as we can see, is much ado about nothing
What you'll get instead is a powerful tearjerker that exposes the Marcoses at their most vulnerable - during their last 72 hours in Malacañang
Even if you're apathetic about the Marcoses, you will still be moved by how Direk Darryl Yap
Is the film perfect
That's too generous of a statement
But it's very well-done
The film is not a hagiography of the Marcoses but it shows them in a more humane light without completely absolving them of their sins
It is a story of family, of love, and of hope
And that's something we can all root for

Good: RECIPEClassic Bananas Foster

By Poppy Tooker Fine Cooking Issue 106

Scott Phillips

(6 ratings)Read Reviews

Save to Recipe Box

Print

Add Recipe Note

Servings: six to eight
Created at Brennan's restaurant in New Orleans in 1951, this classic dessert was named after loyal customer Richard Foster
Firm, ripe bananas are sautéed in a rum-infused caramel sauce, then flambéed in front of diners and spooned over vanilla ice cream
For extra pyrotechnics, throw a pinch of cinnamon onto the sauce as it flames
Read the Test Kitchen blog for tips on flambéing safely
Ingredients2 oz
(4 Tbs
) unsalted butter1 cup lightly packed dark brown sugar1/2 tsp

Ground cinnamon1/4 cup banana liqueur4 firm-ripe bananas, peeled, halved lengthwise, then halved crosswise1/4 cup amber rum, such as Old New Orleans or Goslings1 pint vanilla ice cream

Nutritional Information

PreparationIn a 12-inch skillet, melt the butter over medium heat
Stir in the brown sugar and cinnamon and cook until moist, about 1 minute
Add the banana liqueur and cook, stirring continuously, until the grainy texture disappears and the mixture rolls off the spoon in a steady stream, 1 to 2 minutes
Put the banana quarters rounded side down in the pan
Cook until the bananas begin to soften, 2 to 3 minutes
Turn the bananas onto their flat sides
Remove the pan from the heat and pour in the rum
Set the pan over high heat and carefully ignite the rum with a long match or grill lighter
Gently shake the pan until the flame subsides
Remove from the heat
Place a generous scoop of ice cream in 6 to 8 individual heatproof dessert bowls
Arrange 2 to 3 pieces of sautéed banana around each scoop of ice cream
Spoon on the sauce and serve immediately

The Other Side of History: For a very long time history books and the opposition mainly pictured the Marcos family as despicable and evil, and that Cory Aquino was the one who led the "peaceful" revolution that led to the overthrow of the Marcos Regime
Most of the Filipino people, if not all, were fooled into believing the narrative and lies that the left, the rebels and communists, NPA sympathizers, oligarchs, and student activists peddled

(And now they are going to IMDB to give this movie a low rating because that's what losers do)

The movie showed the other side of that story
The director, Darryl Yap, is successful in making the acting, the story, closer to reality by inserting old video footages of the real happenings around the time of EDSA Revolution in 1986
Yap was able to show the Marcoses as humans who have emotions, too
They were betrayed, frustrated, scared, and feared for their lives as the revolution is not really as peaceful as the opposition claims it to be
It was chaotic and bloody
The best thing about this movie is that the information used to create this masterpiece came from a very reliable source -- one of the maids of the Marcoses in Malacañang
She was able to get herself out of the chaos in the palace by jumping into the Pasig River
The movie is a roller coaster ride of emotions
It made me cry and laugh and mad at times
