The comedy is very cheesy but that also applies to every Filipino movie ever
One complaint I have is the forced dialogue and political potshots but I don't really care that much because

The plot is contained in only 72 hours

2

This was made in the middle of the election where everyone was in "war mode"

FACT OR FICTION

(SPOILER)

There are some elements that are fact and fiction but the history is 100% FACT
S News articles back then showed the extent of the military coup where Malacañang was being peppered with rockets
The protest being violent was also true as there's no such thing as a "peaceful protest" and the movie even shows news clips of brawls between Marcos and Aquino supporters
I saw a negative reviewer here that claimed the maids were just fictional comic relief
The same reviewer admitted that they only watched 30 minutes of the film before storming out of the cinema in anger
This is just false
The big reveal at the end was revealing that these 3 maids were actually real people
One even sadly passed away just two weeks after the events
Almost every Malacañang staff loved the Marcoses and it's a commendable Filipino trait as maids are always treated as part of the family
So the history is actually factual, so where's the fiction
Opinion: Personally I feel that Imee's entire character is fiction
As she heavily contributed to this film, it feels as though this is what she wanted it to have been rather than what actually happened
In the film, Imee is treated as the leader of the household that even her parents can depend on
But witnessing the dynamics of older Ilocano households and even in Bongbong Marcos' own words, the Parents are never questioned and they lead the family by themselves
WHY THE RATING
As stated, my only problems were two elements so 8/10 but overall, it was enjoyable to watch
The solemn scenes are beautifully intermixed with the humorous scenes
It doesn't follow the Filipino extreme like making us think someone's dead only to reveal that they were sleeping
It knows when to put a joke and not interrupt the pacing
The scenes were also heavy
Props to the actors for the performance especially during my favorite scene "Ilocos o Leyte" where Imee has a mental breakdown of paranoia after finding out the severity of the situation
I highly encourage watching with your family (16+) as it's more of a family film than a historical film

Seeing your parents relate to the 80's references makes you feel like your bonding with them and the theme of the entire film is a lesson on how strong family bonds always prevail over petty political fights
Straight from the Fact
: Been watching Most of documentaries specially the Edsa event, and yes it was an unpleasant one, but what we know is just a ONE SIDED one
Now i saw a lot, as in LOTS of supporting documents that are now binding to each other (the missing piece not shown by the media before)
Also some of my titos and titas are more aware of the EDSA REVOLUTION events aside from the biased media telling me that the events are tailored
The movie really showcase the other piece that are kept 37 years ago, specially inside the Malacañang Palace
Well documented and the actors/actress selection are excellent
Big clap for the director of this film
It was a masterpiece, indeed compare to other movies that are pure politics (self given awards) but NOT that great at all
A must-to-see-movie
: Very unorthodox in handling both familial and political issues without compromising every element of film-making
Started to watch Yap's daring and vulgar approach in his previous movies and this is one , I would say deserves a 2-thumbs up

: Just watched Maid in Malacañang a couple of days ago
This is my first time to write a movie review and since I have no expertise in anything related to film production and writing stories, take this as a piece from an ordinary moviegoer
You might come across some strange expressions here, so I'm sorry in advance
TECHNICAL STUFF
Whether it's the cinema's systems or the film's audio mixing, I found the sound so terrible that it affected my experience during the entire time
It was too loud that I had to cover my ears sometimes, even more for the moments when Cristine Reyes as Imee was shouting
And the balance between dialogue and music wasn't great; the Nosi Ba Lasi song didn't fit in well
And I wanted to enjoy the song naman while following the scenes
Another thing is the text
Did they make the text switch too soon or am I just a slow reader
I think it was too fast, and was part of my thought about the story feeling so rushed
Nosi Ba Lasi is the theme song of the film
I didn't pay attention to the lyrics (never listened to the song before) but this version of Sampaguita's song did give some melancholic feeling to the story
Also I wished the background music wasn't so plain
I'm a sucker for movie soundtracks
The music score should have a unique identity
It wasn't memorable
Also the sound of plucking strings during the maids' scenes felt pretentious
Didn't fit in with the sound style of the film
CAST AND CHARACTERS

Okay, so I know nothing about the personalities of the family, so I wanted to see how the film would portray them whether it's assuming we already know the kind of people they are or it's gonna introduce them to us as if they're new (of course, accompanied with the knowledge this film is about the presidential family living at the Palace)
I'm on the latter
I think Imee's introduction was good because I got to know her as this woman who's always moving, got a lot on her mind
When she gets back to the Palace, she's shown as the person most concerned about matters at home
I would be disappointed too if my siblings don't know what to do with their responsibilities haha
So I got the impression that the story would focus more on her development but the film dropped her in the middle of it
Irene, Imelda, and Bongbong suddenly got scenes of their own when I didn't really get to know them before that
(And clearly the father Ferdinand is a secondary character)
Like, okay, I didn't care about their emotionals because I was already hooked on Imee's development from the start
The actors weren't bad actually
Christine Reyes as the stressed out Ate-of-the-house was impressive
Of course, she's the star here
For the other actors, I wasn't really impressed with them
I wish the story was written differently to bring out their best talent
Bruh, I didn't enjoy the pacing
Too much tense and emotional scenes, it felt like a drag
I actually zoned out during Bongbong and Ferdinand's scene
And I saw two people on their phones during that scene too
I was expecting a good breathe of air after that but Irene's scene came next, I think
Hopefully my memory isn't bad
Also maid Biday's presence during that scene felt so out of place
I actually found it funny but it still didn't fit in appropriately
I wish the household staff had more scenes on their own since I felt they were important people in the story
If the story was written to not focus so much on the family but the Palace as a whole, I would've found it more interesting
The balance between serious and comedy needs improvement
Last thing, Robin Padilla's cameo was goddamn too cringe
What is this
The MCU
Welcome to the Malacañang-verse
And IRM 2022 during the Bongbong & Imelda scene was, er, cheesy
THINGS I LIKED
I can't explain how the scene with Ferdinand and Imelda dancing in the middle of the Palace's chaos was nice
Imee's scene with the staff at the end
I think that the only emotional scene I liked
The family cared for the staff and didn't simply abandon them
After Ferdinand called Imee the best maid in the Palace, the fact that the three maids were real people was a (heartwarming) twist
"Maids are not just maids

"

Summary of stars deducted: 1
Terrible sound mixing and musical score was disappointing for a movie soundtrack lover 2
Lack of character exposition and development 3
Story felt like dragging and lost my interest and attention in the middle 4
Robin Padilla cringe and inappropriate comic relief (the maids deserved better
Everything is superb

I definitely recommend this movie, be prepared experience a roller coaster of emotions
The actors were exceptional, especially Christine Reyes
Hands down
Great casting, and amazing cinematography
Standing ovation

Rewatched for the first time since seeing it in the cinemas in 2022

I don't support anything that happened during the Marcos regime, however, I enjoyed the movie then, even now because it was meant to show the helpers/maids who worked in the palace during the People's Revolution
Personally, I grew up always having helpers/yayas and I have tremendous respect for them, and what they do for me and my family
I’ve had helpers who have seen me grow up, took care of me as a child, and some even took part in raising me instead of doing all that for their own children
In the movie, you could see the amount of loyalty the helpers had towards the family, and that’s something that I definitely see every single day with mine

Sometimes, I just think how lucky and how blessed I am to be on the receiving end of things, because they don’t just choose to be a nanny, most times they don't really have a choice, they have to work to send their children to school, put a roof over their families heads, or to just put food on the table and make ends meet
In return, it takes significant moments away from their lives, they take care of somebody else’s kid rather than their own, they take care of somebody else’s mother or father instead of their own
Spending time that can never be given back on making someone’s life easier
Even on the hardest days, they have no choice but to keep going
When theres nothing else they can do but obey what they are being told to do
Even after all of that, they still have a smile on their face, they still do their job to the best of their ability, and for that I will always be grateful

Maid in Malacañang sparked mixed feelings in me
The film lavish portrayal of the Marcos family's final days was captivating, but it felt like it was sugarcoating their brutal legacy
It's a reminder that history is complex, but I worry it might misrepresent the facts
"Masama ba akong tao

"70,000 ang ipinakulong34,000 ang tinorture3,200 ang pinapatayMahigit P300 billion ang ninakaw(Amnesty International, PCGG)Inaasahan ko, at the very least, isa lang 'tong effort to humanize the Marcoses like Downfall

Kaso hindi, ano rin bang ineexpect ko sa walang hiyang direktor na 'to, pinapalabas na para bang taumbayan pa ang masama, na parang hindi inalipin ng kanilang pamilya ang Pilipinas nang mahigit dalawampu't taon (at sa ngayo'y patuloy pa rin), minaliit ang rebolusyon bilang isang pulitikal na agenda ng mga Aquino, at hindi bilang isang makamasang kilusan na nagpabagsak ng diktadurya

Nakakatakot lang talaga yung huling chapter, kasi sa bawat isang makakakita sa katarantaduhang pinapalabas nito, may limang mauuto at maniniwala sa 'totoong kasaysayang' pinaparatang ni Yap, ng mga Marcos, ng mga bumubura at bumabaluktot sa ating kasaysayan - madaling makita ang appeal nito sa masa, napakadaling ipalimot at mabago ang ating pananaw sa pamilya ng isang diktador

Ang pinakamasahol pa ay, ordinaryong mamamayan pa ang ginamit (ang mga kasambahay at PSC) para sa pagpapalaganap ng propagandang Marcos - para lamang sabihing si Imee pala yung "Maid in Malacanang" (no fucking way they did this)
Hanggang ngayon, ginagamit at inaabuso pa rin ng parehong Marcos at Duterte ang taumbayan para sa sari-sariling pulitikal na layunin

Iniisip ko bago 'to panoorin na "Baka bawi naman 'to sa visuals at technical aspects" kaso hindi, ang gimmicky ng long takes, inconsistent yung audio, hindi maayos yung pagpalit from comedy (na hindi rin naman nakakatawa) to drama, ang uncomfortable ng blockings, at ang artificial ng acting ng lahat ng gumanap, high school play lang ang peg
Kahit ganito, naging matagumpay ang pelikula sa nais nitong gawin: hugasan ang pangalan at krimen ng mga Marcos, napa-upo ba naman si Bonget sa palasyo

Pero kahit anong pagbaluktot ang gawin nila sa kasaysayan, kitang kita ngayong ika-39 anibersaryo ng EDSA na tayo pa rin ang may hawak ng kasaysayan, hangga't may hindi nakakalimot, hindi ito mabubura o mapapalitan
1/2 star para sa Traydor na Pag-Ibig ni Marion Aunor, ang ganda ng kanta, pero bakit naman dito ka napunta
Putangina mo Darryl Yap, putangina ng mga Marcos, at putangina ng mga DuterteNever Again, Never Forget

watched (online for free) for a film criticism assignment and holy shit that was such a humbling experience (realized my vocabulary isn't enough to describe how terrible this film is and how much i grieve the time i have spent watching)
marcos family can suck my ass
+ Let's start with the few positives
How this film looks is amazing
Though, for most of the time, people are just standing and exchanging dialogues, the colors of this film really feels like a step-up, relative to Filipino comedies and teleseryes
Also, I guess I liked how it utilized old news footages
And, that's pretty much it
+ Anyways, leaving all politics aside (even though it's hard to do so), if we are going to just view this on the technicality of film making and writing, it's bad
The writing, sound design, and score are overly dramatic clichés you would expect from a family drama, a low-brow comedy, and from a historical and political biopic

Though I appreciate the long takes as it really let's the drama feel natural, however, it also exposes just aforementioned poor writing because it's dialogue that serves nothing to progress the story other than sending their propaganda
+ But truly, one cannot really discuss how this film is written without acknowledging the context of which it arose from
If we really dissect the film, it will not stop bleeding "Marcos Apologist" and historical revisionism
It is also troubling how the film really conveniently is not interested in truly discussing the politics with enough rigor and discipline
It really overly simplifies the entire EDSA People Power to just a dangerous riot orchestrated by power hungry politicians
It leaves out all the complexity of the political climate, as well as all the money laundering which sparked the entire social crisis
Not to mention the violences inflicted during the Martial Law
There really is the sense that Daryll Yap, the director and writer, was only really interested in telling one minute moment of this dark but important part of Philippine history
And he did not even discipline himself enough to not fall prey to self-indulgence
He really wrote it as if its a novel which ironically, made all of the actors in this film feel like they are overacting
+ What is also troubling is how it did not even shy away from truly depicting the regal and glamorous life of the Marcos' in Malacañang
From the number of loyal maids, every wall plastered with life size portraits, easy international travels, among others
And with that kind of glamorous mise en scene, the audacity of this film to mention that the Marcos are not elitists, and that it's the reason for the hate they get
+ Christine Reyes, portraying a younger Sen
Imee Marcos, who happens to be a creative and executive producer of this film, had the highest screen time with acting that knows only to scream frantically
It really is interesting that the senator allowed herself to be depicted and written like this, a controlling paranoid daughter flustered by their family's downfall
And how they revealed she is the Maid in Malacañang
+ And let me just point out how blasphemous this film can get sometimes
Other than the regal mise en scene that competes with churches and their number of Christian iconographies
The scene where President Marcos scolds his son, Bongbong Marcos, the camera gradually and steadily circles around the two as they exchange their dramatic dialogue
The scene is honestly one that I can appreciate because of how it chose to keep this camera circling them technique continue on one long take
But during this long take, there are a handful of moments when the ceiling lights goes behind the President's head resembles a saint with a halo
It's a small nitpick but, dear Jesus, this film really wants to be on the Marcos' good side

+ Another nitpick I want to highlight is how in the scene where Bongbong and Imelda Marcos are talking, they seem to have overestimated the Philippine government after the Dictatorship, stating once they leave, the people of the Philippines would do everything not to let them come back
It does make the audience wonder, and potentially realize the failures of the republic that came after

But what bothers me is this will only paint the democratic and liberal ideas, that should govern us, with yellow And because of it, the discourse of political awareness goes down as just another color contest
And that "IRM 2022" just screams corny
+ There's no substance to this film other than the blatant propagandist nature of it
I recommend watching, not to support this types of film, but to persecute it

Nakakahiya lang…Looking for a movie to assist with Tagalog exposure, I thought this one might stand out amid what looked mostly like a sea of lukewarm romantic comedies
As it happens, this was substantially worse than I could possibly have feared about the others
You know you’re in trouble right from the jump when Imee Marcos is listed as both a creative and executive producer and then turns out to be the main character of the film

I suppose you can’t blame the Marcos clan for trying to further whitewash history now that they’ve fully completed their comeback with the ascension of Bongbong to the presidency a month before this was released, but I almost wonder why they even bothered when the attempt was so dire

This movie is two hours long and it could have cut down to about 20 minutes total - most of the runtime is occupied by interminable scenes of characters saying anything and everything they’re thinking, none of which would be particularly interesting even if most of it weren’t focused on the thesis that Ferdinand Marcos was not an oppressive dictator but rather a Great Man who Loved His People, Actually
Even by Filipino movie standards the overacting is intense - virtually every member of the main cast gets at least one showpiece to absolutely devour the scenery

The actress playing Imee screams so much she must have needed a lozenge by the end of filming (how this was intended as a flattering portrait of a producer of the film I have no idea, but I guess she is referred to as a “genius” multiple times)
This reminded me of nothing so much as the kind of thing that might be dumped out by American *cough* “auteur” Dinesh D’Souza

It evinces absolutely zero talent on the part of anyone involved - the acting stinks, the writing would stink even if the message weren’t horrendous, the tone lurches wildly between melodrama and slapstick for no apparent reason, and the long takes (with their constantly moving camera) are insanely tedious
Paul Thomas Anderson this ain’t
But you actually have to appreciate how badly this is made - if this were a better movie, it might actually have some hope of convincing people of what it’s trying to do
But it’s such a mess it’s hard to imagine anyone getting all the way through unless they’re already enormous Marcos fans or absolute gluttons for punishment like me
For anyone else, don’t waste your time, and I do mean waste
There are easier ways to learn Tagalog than trying to sit through this joke

The film revolves around the Marcos family during their last 72 hours in the Philippines
Witness the other side of this historical event
Those who are too trusting, their enemies may take something from them
It is a lesson of trust, loyalty and truth
The film’s cinematography and soundtrack is outstanding for an independent film

There is so much to dislike about Maid in Malacañang that there is not even one redeeming value in this blatant propaganda movie
The cast performance, which I thought would be the best (and only) part of the movie, ended up being disastrous
Not only they are terribly miscast, but they also don't sound like the Marcos family at all
Even if Christine Reyes had the "best" acting in this movie, it does not say much when she doesn't even look like Imee Marcos and the dialogue is terribly written

All of the budget to make them look accurate to the Marcoses went to Ruffa Guitterez's wig as Imelda and the filmmakers are lazily relying on the viewers to identify which one is who in the Marcos family
The cinematography is also not good
The use of pseudo "one-take" shot framing using the square aspect ratio to highlight the film's time period just makes this film so ugly and ingenuine
It's like I am watching a poorly-edited Lana Del Rey music video
The Vincentiments humor in some of the scenes is just terrible and very out-of-place for a period film like this
This is what you get for a film written by someone whose previous background in filmmaking was tacky sex comedies
Perhaps the most offensive part of this film is that it attempts to put the entire family in a positive light as if they are not held responsible for the things that took place during Martial Law

To justify their lapses, the film instead presents the Marcoses as genuinely good people who happen to be naive and absent-minded about the people who betrayed them and Imee (who is the film's main POV and the real-life senator is also a producer of the movie) happens to be the only smart one in the family
I just cannot fantom how people fall for this obvious lie, yet their supporters will take them as facts on the surface
It's so annoying how films like Maid in Malacañang, as well as its counter-programming film Katips, only aim to fuel our culture war here in the Philippines

Both of these films are only made to strengthen the confirmation bias of their target audience, forcing them to accept whatever they presented as facts instead of asking the audience to ponder the message they want to tell
Among all of the bad-to-mediocre Martial Law and post-ML era films made since President Bongbong Marcos became president, this is the worst one of the bunch
Never again
A gross spectacle in hindsight, one that embraces and glorifies every single form of manipulative and almost fascistic appeal from the characters
It's rather devoid of any sort of emotion and dipped into an endless pit of constant egotism by Darryl Yap that it's embarrassing to look at

When we are introduced to Marcos family, the first thing they with the large and spacious hallways of their palace, filled to the brim with gold, maids, and a polish mansion with never a single flaw in hindsight
When we are then introduced to the protesters, it's through low-angle shots, a filter of uneducated and poor peasants that almost sees them as derogatory of any kind
A film both ville and technically incompetent in direction
You can compare this to films such as Birth of a Nation or Triumph of Will, but at least those two films have clear reason and direction on why they exist a propaganda
In Maid In Manacalang, everything is so convoluted that it almost feels like a parody on Facebook rather than something to take seriously with
This film isn't even about any maids, and they probably just served as a light cover-up with the marketing
I hope Luis Bunuel comes back from the dead to make Darryl Yap live the events of "Un Chien Adalou"
Historically distorted films have marred history for decades now
Certain movies like Argo, Braveheart, Pocahontas, and Patton had their fair share of twisting history in exchange for spectacle
Even movie juggernauts like Lawrence of Arabia or Titanic have been lambasted because they portray actual events
The difference between those films and this is that they have been created with cinematic accuracies that provide enjoyment to the audience
In the eyes of the filmmakers, what matters most is if the movie generates income, even if it's executed poorly story-wise and technicality-wise
Maid in Malacañang, despite its well-divided 10-chapter plot, is a mixture of unnecessary inconsistencies shown in a very cheap spectacle style
Inconsistent shots that tried to execute long takes, like in 1917 or Birdman, but the character blockings and setup make it more annoying than pleasing
Cheap sets used to represent the Malacañan Palace (The grandest mansion in the Philippines) looked like a huge village home full of creaks and poor paints
Mixing in 21st Century Gen-z dialogues to add humor that doesn't work well
And line delivery seemed like the actors tried to portray their roles because they were asked to and did not practice well
But I got to say, it takes a lot of heart and brains to really watch this one
Because to me, who has watched a good chunk of films, especially award-winning ones, made this film more annoying than enjoyable even if you don't bother comparing it to actual history
I know we are not always gunning for our movies to be "world-class" because filmmaking is still a business, and sales are more important because it generates money
Maid in Malacañang is definitely a tad below the low-class filmmaking because the whole movie felt like it was done in a rush, like a school project
Yet, it was still watched by a lot of people
I am wondering, have our standards on how we watch films gotten really low
I'll stay neutral on this one
The fuk
I did my best to view this film in an objective manner
The film is "meh" at best and just a waste of time at worst
The pacing is so slow for the majority of the film
This could have easily been a 45-minute TV special but no they had to have a 2-hour runtime
There were a lot of long rolling takes that had no point of being long rolling takes
It's just for style over substance
The acting…

Fresh from the success of winning the Philippines' 2022 Presidential elections through their endless propaganda and trolling, Darryl Yap brings us his latest pessimus opus: the fictionalized retelling of the end of Marcos family's dictatorship, focusing on their last three days in Malacañang Palace before their exile in Hawaii following the People Power Revolution in 1986

In the film, Cristine Reyes play the fictionalized version of Imee Marcos, who returns to the Philippines after she is summoned by his father, a fictional, mild-mannered version of Ferdinand Marcos (played by Cesar Montano)
Upon returning to the film's cheap-looking version of Malacanang, the fictional version of Imee Marcos learns about a failed assassination plot against their family

All throughout the film's excessively long running time, the fictional version of the Marcos family face betrayal of several high-ranking officials, including several Palace staff, food shortages, plus fear and anxiety from the growing number of the "mindless" crowds joining the EDSA revolution

After ten excruciating chapters and 105 wasted minutes, the family, upon the persuasion of the fictional version of Imee, decides to leave the Palace, with the help of m0therfvcking senator Robin Padilla as Gen
Fabian Ver, the Chief of Staff of the AFP under the Marcos Administration
The film ends with people storming the Palace, looting and destroying its premises

Penned and directed by Yap, with the real Imee Marcos serving as the film's creative producer, this propaganda film is actually not the worst Filipino film of 2022 for me (that recognition still belongs to the Claudine Barretto revenge drama "Deception")
But this is definitely the most boring local film from last year

The film opens with a text saying the following: " Ang pelikulang ito ay naglalaman ng mga tunay na kaganapan, sa gitna ng kasaysayan, sa gilid ng kaguluhan, sa likod ng media, na ngayo'y ihaharap sa Bayan
" Early on, it already conditions the viewers' minds that what they're about to see is based on a true story
It even used real life footage and clips from the time of the EDSA revolution to make it feel more "real
" There's even a voice-over, claiming that Cory Aquino herself was advocating for the public's civil disobedience
We all know how it's going to end, with Marcoses as mere victims of fate and tragedy
Nothing is surprisng anymore
In short, their version of the truth, so it's predictable from the get-go
Kuwento niyo yan, eh
On top of this, the forced comedy makes it even more painful to watch
Can you imagine, the actual "maids" in the movie are the ones that make it more cringy, acting like some chorus and providing comic relief (which all failed)
Karla Estrada and Beverly Sarmiento in particular, are both excruciating to watch and listen to
It feels more like a series of Vincentiments skit with bigger names, stitched together to form a film
It also looks like one
It's cheap
It's boring
It's always loud (lots of shouting, as usual)
It's very dependent on stirring controversy
Very Darryl Yap
Right from its early scenes, the film's main focus is on the fictionalized version Imee Marcos, making it feel like she's the hero of the story

It's actually pretty confusing, because I remember the real Imee Marcos saying before that she was "too young" when she heard about Martial Law, but here, she's portrayed as a full-grown, fierce and intelligent woman, which we all know are all made up, just like her claim that she is "one of the first female graduates from an Ivy League School -- Princeton University, graduating with honors
"And as expected, it paints Ferdinand Marcos as a naive and innocent victim who trusted the wrong people, and the entire family as sad victims
"Palagi lang mabait
Yan, yan yung ginamit nila para mapagbagsak ka
Sobrang tiwala mo sa kanila," said the fictional version of Imee

They did get one detail right though: that young Bong-bong is a party animal, as proven by their massive private video collection obtained by the media, including the infamous "We Are The World" video during his birthday celebration on board the presidential yacht Ang Pangulo
To make matters worse, all the scenes lack tension
They all feel dull, despite how loud the characters shout their lines
The only thing that adds emotions to its scenes is its manipulative and overbearing music
The cinematography employs long shots which, instead of giving the film an authentic feel, makes it look more boring
The performances only add up to the film's blandness, like Ruffa Gutierrez's performance, who looks like she doesn't know any other facial expressions
She's like Jennifer Coolidge, but in a very bad way
You don't know whether she's about to laugh, about to cry, or she's just constipated
The only good decision that this film had is having Cristine Reyes playing the improved, cinematic version of Imee
It's packed with lies after lies, that it is so hard to keep track
"Galit na galit sila dahil hindi tayo nanggaling sa elitistang angkan
Galit na galit sila dahil probinsyano lang tayo
Galit na galit sila dahil mahal tayo ng mga tao
Pero hindi ko magawang magalit sa kanila," says the sadboi ex-President in the movie
And I'm not even going to dig further in that scene featuring Giselle Sanchez's portrayal of Cory Aquino playing mahjong with nuns, which has been debunked by the Carmelite sisters themselves

Long, loud, lame and lifeless, this fictionalized, propagandist film from Viva Films and Darryl Yap is nothing more than a disgusting attempt to whitewash the crimes and atrocities under the Marcos dictatorship, and to suck-up to the current administration

Finally got to see the year's most controversial film
(Currently ranks as the 3rd highest grossing Filipino film* of all-time
as well as the fourth lowest rated film on all of Letterboxd right now
)I think Yap is just too stupid and lazy for this film to be *truly* offensive; as it is, it just plays out as the sort of propaganda whose only goal is to preach to the converted
The Marcoses are depicted as paragons of virtue, unfairly maligned by the ignorant (and jealous) activists/media who've always despised them
There's never any mention as to WHY these activists are so angry--no menton of the thousands of victims of the dictatorship
No, Ferdinand Marcos's only crime (according to this) is that he loved his country too much
I'd like to be charitable--one could defend this by saying that, since this film is only from the perspective of the Marcoses and their staff, that of course the result will be hero-worship
that in fact, he's making a critical view of him by showing how brainwashed his inner circle was
except Yap can't even do that, as he inserts newsreel footage and chapter headings that all promise he's showing us "the TRUE story" of the PPP

And the ending--Cory Aquino's lone appearance, gambling with nuns and heartlessly ordering the Marcos's exile--completely scraps that possibility (as it depicts Aquino as a monster, and it's also a scene no one in the Marcos family witnesses--it's all Yap
)That said: on a formal level, the film is really interesting

The average shot length is about 3 minutes each, and they're not lazy stationary ones; Yap will start a scene outside the palace, then go indoors, up the stairs, into different rooms, with dialogue from multiple actors, all without a cut

I don't quite know why he's doing that, but it's a really neat touch, as most of the film is comprised of conversations, and I'm always a sucker for shooting those at a distance with shots as long as possible--it's the best way to capture performance, imo

And the odd music cues (it starts with an 80s dance version of an OPM classic "Nosi Balasi"), random interjections of humor (from the maids), and odd bookends of scenes (a maid ends her Big Speech to the palace staff by asking one for a candy bar), it's all very interesting
yet totally at odds with the rest of the film which is blunt and brutal
*That’s what Wikipedia says, but I’ve learned that the box office figures for this were almost certainly inflated artificially

as with all things in life, one must take this film with a grain of salt - obviously you have to when imee marcos is a producer - and they absolutely are trying to whitewash the marcos family, even romanticize them
thus, the way to view this film is as a window to how delusional the marcoses and their supporters are
in this way, it becomes a fascinating and at times hilarious watch (often unintentionally)
the extent to which daryl yap tries to humanize the marcoses is so over the top it is comical
it’s not that humanizing the marcoses is a sin - it’s the @$$ kissing that makes one rolls their eyes
and there’s plenty of it here

nonetheless, i found this to be more entertaining than basically any lav diaz film i’ve seen, and less offensive than the racist film of (the otherwise great auteur) mike de leon (both of whom - rightfully so - are marcos critics)

at least with maid in malacanang i knew what to expect - diaz is so pretentious i dgaf how much my politics align with his, and the fact that filipinos ignore the (not even casual) racism of kakabakaba ka ba really makes me want to bash my brains out
as if fawning over the royal family of england is any different than the fanaticism of marcos supporters, but one is more acceptable to certain filipino cinephiles than the other

[ahahaha if u saw my profile yes I watched this, but I also watched Katips as well- ALSO NO I WATCHED THIS FILM ONLINE JUST LIKE KATIPS]Okay before anything, I'm not a kakampink or Marcos Loyalist [and I don't care about political labels] so if you don't like my opinion cuz it doesn't align with your political views, then don't read my post from here

I've heard of Darryl Yap before [Via vincentiments] but I wasn't interested in his works- since I found most of them to be disrespectful and controversial, yet ig that's the style he likes or made him relevant anyways

So, I watched this film with a neutral thought-and I knew that this would focus on the Marcoses' (Obviously cuz Imee helped him produce it) last hours in Malacanang (yk when they were ousted in 1986), and I never really thought about it but yea I never heard their side of the story when it came to their last hours there

[Okay this is where all the political shenanigans happen so please respect my opinion huhuhu]Well, it's rare to see a film talk about the Marcoses on a less-evil note - unless bloggers talk about them, so there was kinda a gap for me when it came to perceiving Marcos Sr
as a father than as a strongman
It wasn't my cup of tea at first, but ig he was also a person who had his flaws IN THE FILM
The actor portrayed him pretty well, the same goes for Bongbong and the rest
I also liked how they centered this more on family issues than political issues tho
And wow They sure had their conflicts
I just didn't like how they kinda rushed on some parts, or overly exaggerated the maids
Storyline: Engaging and interesting, yet had some plotholes
[3/5]Characters: OKAY OUTSIDE THE ACTUAL MARCOSES, the characters in the film were good
[4/5]Music: Meh
[2/5]Overall: 9/15 - again I'm not a Marcos supporter [or even a Leni supporter] - but okay the film was decent
Relieved I didn't see this in the cinemas, but well it did reach my low expectations

Badly-written, lazily-directed and saddled with terrible-pacing, wooden acting and a scattershot plot, Maid in Malacañang is Filipino Film Director Darryl Yap's vanity project whose sole raison d'etre seems be laundering the ignominious reputation of one of history's worst kleptocratic dictators Ferdinand Marcos Sr
along with his equally corrupt family (a reputation surpassed only by Suharto in pilfering his respective nation's coffers)
Indeed, the project was concieved with the deposed despot's own unrepentant daughter Senator Imee Marcos serving as its "creative producer"
With all of these elements at play, one can't help but think this film is just bad propaganda and self-serving hagiography
It brings nothing new to the table nor does it contribute to the advancement of the moviemaking craft
If that's not bad enough, Yap makes amateurish directorial missteps such as telling the story instead of showing it
The only positive the film possess is the fact the producers clearly spent money on its set pieces
With Maid in Malacañang, Yap ascends to the list of ignominious filmmakers such as Leni Riefenstahl and D
Griffith but with far less talent
Yap is certainly no auteur
Historical revisionism at it's finest
Literally rewriting history, no wonder Filipinos today believe on myths on how the Marcos era was "the golden age"
Basically, a propaganda movie to white-washed the dark history of the family of Marcos
It garners dimwitted audience who doesn't read historical records and fanatics of the said family
Like Imelda Marcos' one famous quote from the Kingmaker documentary "Problem with media is the gun can kill you only up to the grave

Media can kill you beyond the grave", they sure are very aware of the historical distortion they are doing that's why they hired social media specialist or trolls to divide the people through populism

In an article titled "Recovery of the Marcos Assets," former PCGG Commissioner Jaime Bautista recalls that the William Saunders-Jane Ryan accounts were closed by 1970 but its balances were transferred to the Xandy Foundation, which was later transferred to Fides Trust Co
and then to Avertina Foundation
This is only one of several foreign foundations that the Marcoses established as supposed cover-up for their money deposited in the Swiss banking system
The Swiss Federal Supreme Court ruled that the secret Marcos account hidden in Swiss banks had criminal provenance
The high court ordered its transfer to the Republic of the Philippines and placed it under escrow with the Philippine National Bank
In 1998, Switzerland turned over to the Philippines bank deposits worth $627 million in accordance with the Swiss Federal Supreme Court

The Marcos foundations appealed to prevent the transfer of bank deposits to the Philippines but the Swiss Federal Supreme Court ruled that the foundations were mere creations of Marcos and that they had participated in his bad faith

None exist this so-called historical revisionism as Maid in Malacañang is all about its interfamilial drama
The highs and (mostly) lows of the royal-esque family are narrated from their side of the story albeit with imprudence
They try so hard to make the Marcoses look more appealing, but they don’t even try to make the movie actually decent
I thought movies were supposed to mostly show, not tell
Why the hell are there just long walls of texts in between “chapters”
Okay, so you say the Marcoses are doing this and feeling that, so why don’t you just show it to us
You’ve got an ENTIRE set of actors and you instead just ask us to read the “struggles” they supposedly felt
Instead of the maids just telling stories about how kind the Marcoses are to them, why not actually show the Marcoses doing special things for the maids
Telling instead of showing is not entirely bad, but a little more effort here please
Which brings me to my next point…2
There is a lack of—or honestly, complete absence of—thought in the visuals
Okay, we got the 80s square ratio and sepia tones which seems to be nothing more than an aesthetic of the time period, but what about the cinematography and the staging
The camera seems to hesitantly step in and out because the frame is somehow not fitting everyone in LOL
the way the camera quickly rotates 180 degrees from person to person is offbeat; it looks like a Bong Joon-ho sequence done wrong
Why is it that most of these scenes are just long ass takes with the camera rotating 360 degrees

In one scene, a conversation between BBM and FEM had the camera just continuously circles around the two actors who don’t move from their positions at all—there’s not a care whether the facial expressions of the speaker or the reactor are more important to be shown at a certain moment
In another scene between BBM and Imelda, the camera watches them on the bed from above and just rotates endlessly… to what
Symbolize me spiraling out of control
They literally spend no time setting up the characters
It’s clear who they wrote this story for because you already have to be emotionally invested to relate to any of them
Naiyak daw sila kay Ella Cruz after having her show up for one crying scene with FEM after having no dad-daughter interaction in an earlier scene
Ano ‘to

Siya ang babaeng Ferdinand Marcos

Just ugly on historic levels
Take a 360° look at the last 72 hours of the Marcoses in the presidential palace at the height of the EDSA Revolution in 1986
Highly controversial due to its subject matter, it gives voice to the infamous family that has never told its most vulnerable stories before
Passionately crafted by its equally controversial director Darryl Yap, this is his first drama film and Viva Films' first major theatrical event in the time of pandemic

Its ensemble cast consists of respectable actors, but special mention to three standout performances: Cesar Montano, who also previously played the hero Jose Rizal in the 90s, has effectively humanized the late Ferdinand Marcos Sr
as a father
The father-and-son confrontation was very powerful, more so that he shared the scene with his real-life son, Diego Loyzaga
Cristine Reyes as the eldest daughter Imee carried the film's tense moments on her shoulders and her indomitable presence brought the entire household together in its darkest hours

Beverly Salviejo utilized her theatrical chops as the housemaid Biday and she balanced all the drama with her genuinely funny antics that in one scene with her fellow maids, you'd see yourself cry then laugh then cry again
This is a family story at its very core, a dramatization of their final hours as a powerful first family and before their lives are changed forever
I like how every chapter incorporates real news footage or context then it portrays how it was like in the palace as these historical moments unfold
The soundtrack captures the mood and makes certain scenes unforgettable
The film evokes the feel of watching a theatrical play with its continuous shots and reliance on dialogue
However, this is in no way a perfect film
While it mainly focuses on the characters' interactions, there are certain parts of conversations that I believe are unnecessary and could've been ommitted
Since it's a period piece, there were some (humorous) utterances more common in our current day and age that it's ridiculous to hear them in 1986
The camera works need more polishing especially in the continuous scenes, there are times when the framing or angle techniques could be a bit distracting to the viewers (and to the actors too)
Plus, I would love to see more of Imelda than in the very few scenes she's in
And for the million dollar question: Does the film blatantly revise history as we know it
Well, you'd be disappointed to find this is not the film all them noisy people are claiming it to be
The emotional outbursts on where the family's persecution was coming from could be heavily debated, but these were the family's inner thoughts in the midst of chaos
The controversial Cory scene is simply as it is, aptly symbolizing the 'game' of politics after EDSA
All in all, you'll feel roller-coaster emotions for the characters you've only heard bad things about, and you'll see them in the perspective of the closest people who were actually THERE
In fact, the thing that moved me the most is realizing that they are as real as you and I, and that far from being historians, at least they have finally spoken their truth
And the rest, they say, is history

Watched "Maid in Malacañang" at SM Sangandaan Cinema 2
Smart clever HARMLESS insightful art film that does not actually distort history on its main story

But as a committed Marcos sympathy apologist filmMaid in Malacañang is such a WEAK pro-Marcos propaganda filmThat can be easily debunked, disputed called-out or trashed out by reply films made by REAL Filipino filmmakers calling out the horrific facts of the brutal Marcos dictatorshipWaiting to watch those stronger reply films shouting #NeverAgain to Marcos Martial Law
Contrary to the rabid noise on social media claiming that this movie is made out of malicious lies meant for historical revisionism

I'm surprised that "Maid In Malacañang" does NOT revise distort our collective Philippine history about the brutal & corrupt Marcos regime,The film actually embraces our ACTUAL history about the impeding end of the Marcos dictatorship
It even acknowledges some of the grave sins of the Marcos regime such as blatantly bribing local leaders to maintain political clout, the lavish lifestyle brought by absolute dictatorship etc
Even accepting the dictator's political playbook that a dictator's rule would not last forever
The brutal Marcos dictatorship, as well as other dictatorships around the world will surely end
Not a question of if it would end but when
And the Marcoses accept that historical FACT and not denying it
So "Maid In Malacañang" is not just a movie about the last hours of the Marcos dictatorship
But it is also a powerbank of emotional hugot and sentiments from the point of view of Marcos along with his last loyalists standing in Malacañang at this turning point of our ACTUAL history
It is obviously clear that the movie does not distort nor revise history on its main story
But the film artistically uses unreliable narration recalling events of the historic last moments of the Marcos dictatorship

Using "tsismis" accounts from the feeble-minded maids who reflect typical Filipino masses who do not know much but still stands by their own version of any real-life stories via unfounded rumors or "tsismis"

And using such rumors from naive commonfolk where their little world just revolves inside Malacañang is a legitimate social commentary on the reality that the Filipino masses do not know the real story, standing firm on knowing historical or current events based on hearsays, rumors and "tsismis"
This is a social commentary FACT and not "tsismis" at all

And the film still utilizes unreliable narration of past historical events of the Marcos regime based from testimonies from the Marcos childrenWho spend most of their youth living carefree lives not minding what's happening in our country governed by their brutal dictator of a father for more than two decades

It would be understandable for the Imee or Bongbong character in the film to "claim" that their dictator father was betrayed, deceived or colluded by his supposed "trusted minions" in the dictatorship
That could be their opinion, baseless emotional rants or understanding on what happened based from their little world which may or may not be true

Everyone of us has biased opinions or varying levels of understanding from factual historical eventsEspecially on crucial moments where emotions ran high and the beleaguered may not think well anymore succumbing to delusions and the 5 stages of grief
So the historical events of the last moments of the Marcos dictatorship still remains intact without any historical revisionism or distortion

What we witness in the film are emotional rants, hugots and dangling opinions & perspectives of the royal Marcos household as they are facing the final curtain of their golden era of the Marcos dictatorship
The Marcos family depicted in "Maid In Malacañang" is NOT who the Marcoses actually are
The Marcos family is clandestine
They keep an inner circle where they secretly live as they actually are
The Filipino masses & the international community do not actually know who the Marcoses really are
Being a masterful Filipino political family, the Marcoses like to keep a front or a political facade of a public image infront of the people

The Marcoses like veteran politicians would want to contruct their public image based on what the Filipino people would want to see and based on what the Marcoses themselves would want the Filipino people to know about them

So "Maid in Malacañang" with artistic license, superficially & cinematically portray the Marcoses based on what the Filipino audience would want to see from them or based on what the film or producers would want the Filipino audience to see about the Marcoses with a specific objective to win their sympathy

This is why I doubt if the Marcoses do speak in Tagalog most of the time or the Marcos children are very knowledgeable or fully aware of their father's dictatorship to the point that they can try to take control of the dangerous situation that the Marcos family were into
Cesar Montano is the worst actor to portray the dictator Ferdinand Marcos
He does not resemble nor act like the real Ferdinand Marcos
Cesar Montano seems to be a fraud of a Marcos in the film

Ruben Rustria is still the best actor that convincingly portay the late strongman Ferdinand Marcos in the Australian film "A Dangerous Life" which we Filipinos watched on ABS-CBN Channel 2 after the EDSA Revolution
Ruffa Gutierrez in fairness does resemble first lady Imelda Marcos in a way as Imelda has white skin similar with Ruffa
However, Tessie Tomas although morena still delivers an iconic role as Imelda Marcos as a kingmaker of a first lady also in "A Dangerous Life"
However, Ruffa Gutierrez is given little acting or significance in "Maid in Malacañang"
Such an odd choice from the director as Imelda Marcos remains to be a very iconic & very fascinating political figure in the world
Both Cesar Montano and Ruffa Gutirrez give very lame performance as the once powerful Marcos dictator couple
But I cannot blame them for they are not the main characters of the movie
I'm surprised that the Marcos children are the main characters in which "Maid In Malacañang" is all about
Particularly the Imee Marcos character who is actually the lead character in the film
Although the Bongbong Marcos character delivered an interesting scene throwing barbs with his father

So "Maid In Malacañang" does not really revise or distort history in its main story but only utilizes unreliable narration and equally unreliable yet raw impactful emotional sentiments of the unreliably cinematically stylized Marcos family as they face the final chapter of the dictator's playbook on that fateful event
Inspite of employing unreliable narration and sentiments,The artistic messaging is very clear in "Maid In Malacañang"
The reign of the once mighty Marcos dictator couple is about to end and they are both resigned & disillusioned with their fate & the end of their legacy
But the Marcos children remains strong & defiant seemingly taking charge of moving on and reclaiming the honor of the Marcos family moving forward

The Marcoses has accepted factual history of the end of their dictatorshipBut they willfully draw sentiments, sympathies & even pity from the Filipino peopleAs the Marcoses still uphold their pride, honor & dignity even at the lowest point of their lives
So the film does not intend to revise or distort history in its main story
For the Marcoses themselves accept their place in history as it is
But they make sure that they would use factual history to turn back in their favor
I heard Imelda Marcos mention about using history in their favor in an old news clip
And this film truly reaffirms the determination of the Marcoses to make factual history work for their favor

The film is obviously a Marcos apologist, sympathizing propaganda moviePrimarily catering to the Marcos loyalist & supporters seeking vindication from the recent win of Bongbong Marcos making another Marcos our President right now

But at the same time, the film also caters to REAL Filipinos like me who remember & despise the brutal despotic Marcos dictatorship and who value the EDSA Revolution and the return of Philippine democracy that Marcos has nefariously taken away from us Filipinos
So "Maid In Malacañang" along with its story caters to BOTH pro-Marcos and anti-Marcos alike

With the same emotional blurbs & sentiments where the Marcoses try to redeem their legacy and consoling themselves that the Marcoses has done great for the Philippines and is a poor victim of betrayal from his "political minions" wanting to grab (dictator
) power from him

For REAL Filipinos like me who despite Marcos brutal dictatorship, I pity & looked down at the Marcoses in the film with their disillusionment & delusions as they bitterly accept their humiliating fate with their destined end of their typical dictator's saga

But for the rabid Marcos loyalists & dumb random Filipino audience who just wants to spend time in the cinema, they can get enamored and easily sympathize with the Marcos with those same scenes & lines
Especially with that scene where the Cesar Montano Ferdinand Marcos whimsically said that the elites want to oust him from power for he is just a "simple probinsyano"
For REAL Filipinos like me, that's laughable & very pathetic for the once mighty dictator to say that

But for the Marcos loyalists & dumb Filipino masses watching the movie, that line may resound on them which would effectively sympathize & root for the Marcoses simply for being also a "simple probinsyano"
This same "Maid In Malacañang" film caters to both pro-Marcos, anti-Marcos and even to those who do not give a damn about the Marcoses
The same theme & scenes caters to the most politically polarized affinity with different persepectives on the same film
In the film, the dictator Marcos character in the film explicitly calls his daughter, the Imee Marcos character in the film the "Maid in Malacañang"
I think Senator Imee Marcos divulged a secret family joke about her during the Marcoses' long stay in Malacañang
But what is very interesting in the film are the "Maids in Malacañang" portrayed in the film
These maids are tools for the film to enforce unreliable narration by relying on "tsismis" to interpret history
And those maids provide some humor and comic relief to the film
But the cinematic significance of the maids in the film are more profound and more poetic than being just comic reliefs
Director Darryl Yap actually lives up with the title of the film and puts those "Maids in Malacañang" into the pedestal driving the message and its ideology on the film
He promoted those maids from being comical extras for the cinematic Marcos family into a compelling symbol representing the Filipino people as a whole
Karla Estrada has delivered the most powerful and convincing role in her showbiz career with "Maid In Malacañang"
Director Darryl Yap made a once underrated Kim Molina into a star in the well-acclaimed #Jowable

Now he has rewarded Karla Estrada with a supposed-to-be simple extra role into a metaphorical character on how the Filipino people are treated & see themselves as the maids & helpers of the Marcos dynasty in Malacañang
This is an amazing feat
Karla Estrada should thank Darryl Yap for giving her an important, substantial role of her lifetime

That scene where Yaya Karla Estrada rallies all the maids & Malacañang household members to come to terms with what they would do after the Marcos would leave & mad demonstrators are marching into Malacañang, is truly a cinematic game-changer unraveling the metaphorical strengths of the film
Finally, those seemingly lowly maids & other Malacañang househeld members are given an important symbol unraveling the UNTOLD TRUTH that "Maid in Malacañang" would unravel
Those maids in Malacañang do not only represent the Marcos loyalists
They also represent all of us Filipinos in general

As we Filipinos during the entire Marcos dictatorship see ourselves & are regarded by Marcos & everyone around the world as mere maids, helpers of the royal Marcos family & wilfull enablers of the Marcos dictatorship or any corrupt regime
This metaphor is so convincingly TRUE
I'm so amazed
The film has started to unravel the UNTOLD TRUTH on "Maid In Malacañang"
The film attempts to pack a big punch at the final scene depicting the siege in Malacañang marking the tangible end of the Marcos dictatorship
First of all, this final scene of "Maid In Malacañang" is the start of its HISTORICAL DISTORTION
The historical portrayal of the siege in Malacañang is oh so WRONG
The rallyists sieging the Presidential Palace are all not wearing yellow
Some or even most of them are reds
The rallyists are not actually mostly Cory Aquino supporters
Many of the rallyists sieging Malacañang are Joma Sison Communist followers
So it clearly explains why those rallyists seiging Malacañang exhibit very unruly and raging behavior
After all these years of being oppressed by the Marcos Dictatorship, they understandably vent their extreme rage & anger in Malacañang hoping to capture the Marcoses inside the palace
I personally took part of the EDSA Revolution
Many the REAL Filipinos in the EDSA Revolution are not seiging Malacañang

I as well as many of the EDSA Revolution participants wearing yellow are in EDSA in Quezon City, particularly along our AFP military Camp Aguinaldo and our Police headquarters Camp Crame trying to form a massive human blockade to protect our military hero, Fidel V
Ramos & other prominent revolutionaries from being attacked by the loyal Marcos forces
There could be yellow supporters marching to Malacañang but many of them are Communist militant activists
So "Maid In Malacañang" is OH SO WRONG portraying the rallyists all wearing yellow
Many of them should wear Communist red when seiging to Malacañang as an actual & fair depiction of history
But Director Darryl Yap made an undignified choice to distort historical justice over poetic justice as he is trying to make a statement out of the so-called "Yellow" seige in Malacañang
Just treat this Malacañang seige scene not as a historical account but rather as a cinematic metaphorical statement unveiling the UNTOLD TRUTH from the movie
That so-called Malacañang seige scene powerfully states that the Filipino masses are really not genuinely invested in revolutions
Revolutions come and go
The Filipino masses would naturally join the revolution only if they see that it benefits their little lives
It's not about being patriotic
The Filipino masses join the revolution only for their little vested self-interest
And that is the UNTOLD FACT that caught me by surprise watching this Darryl Yap film
Revolutions come and go
Along with those in power and other politicians who come and go with the times
That's the TRUTH
Naglunsad ng rebolusyon ang masang Pilipino HINDI dahil sa pagiging makabayan kung hindi para sa kanilang maliit na sariling interes
At iyan talaga ang KATOTOTHANAN sa buhay
Pana-panahon lang ang rebolusyon
Pana-panahon lang ang mga nasa kapangyarihan
Pana-panahon lang ang pulitika
This is where the highly creative artistic talent of Director Darryl Yap come to play in this film
Just as when the main story has ended and the film had made a credible point
Director Darryl Yap has to make Marvel-MCU-like mid-credits scenes that stir real repulsive controversy that would drag down the film
Giselle Sanchez's depiction of Democracy Icon Cory Aquino is her worst acting ever that could damage her career
That post-credit scene where Cory play mahjong with the Carmelite Sisters in Cebu is a malicious smear to the undisputed Revolutionary and Democracy Icon
It's even a blatant attack on the Carmelite Sisters as well
But at least this is considered to be a post-credit scene that is actually not an integral part of the main story and message of the film

This malicious scene could be easily taken away on future releases on television, Vivamax & other streaming sites & on official physical copies,In case the Carmelite Sisters or the Aquino estate would file an injuction order to the courts against the film
But that mahjong scene is part of Darryl Yap's cinematically poetic metaphor reinforcing its message that no political ruler or ideology would last forever
Panahon-panahon lang ang pulitika
As there is also a mahjong scene in Imee Marcos's residence at the beginning of the film
And that Robin Padilla cameo scene truly shows that he's a sellout
I remembered his past interviews that he idolizes Che Guevarra & other armed revolutionaries
Now he portrayed a "rebel" solidier who pretended to be a rebel but approached the Marcoses to show his loyalty to the dictator family
So Robin Padilla projecting his bad boy, rebel, revolutionary persona on movies is nothing but a farce
Robin Padilla is truly a sell-out and a tool
So yes
"Maid In Malacañang" is a creative decent art film that does not primarily alter, revise or distort our Philippine history, except for the last scene out of "poetic justice"
The film embraces actual history accepting the fate of the Marcoses falling from grace as their dictatorship is collapsing in front of them just as stipulated from a dictator's playbook
But inspite of the Marcos's downfall, they still put their heads up high and salvage whatever dignity is left from them to finally leave the Philippines effectively ending their brutal dictatorship
This is what the film is all about
Very harmless, accessible and even interesting
This could have been another good film by Director Darryl Yap (Yet way inferior to his acclaimed landmark film #Jowable which is truly great
Whatever the film says makes it good
However, whatever the film DOES NOT SAY, makes it truly BAD
The film continues to depict the Marcoses as the fallen victims of their impending doom
And those angry rallyists storming Malacañang really look rabid and inhumane (Since most these rallyists are actually rabid Communist militant activists who should be wearning red not yellow
The film keeps on stressing that the Marcoses are betrayed, coerced & are ousted for the patriarch is a probinsyano which is utterly ridiculous
But what the film FAILED to show is the background behind the call to oust Marcos from power
Surely, there are actual historical reasons why there are loud clamors for the Marcos to finally step down and to get out of the Philippines
It's surprising that "Maid In Malacañang" does not mention the Marcos dictatorship and Martial Law itself
The film does not let the Marcos characters reflect or retrospect their 20+ years of Marcos rule and dictatorship

The film does not even justify why the elder President Marcos has to declare Martial Law and even address the Cold War & Communist insurgency as an excusable reason for Marcos to declare Martial Law and rule as a dictator in order to save the Philippines
No refelections or justifications are made on the First Quarter Storm, Martial Law & the Marcos dictatorship ruling with an iron first
All that the Imee Marcos character has been saying and all the rants & sympathetic statements made by the cinematic Marcos family in the film are all ended up as just whims
Nothing substantial
No powerful statements spoken
Only whims
There are lots of good stories about the Marcos dictatorship that can be made into films which could be way better than this WEAK Darryl Yap movie

Perhaps narrating the context & events behind President Bongbong Marcos walking along Chinese Communist leader Mao Ze Dong would be a great idea for a movie that would put the Marcoses in a good respectable reputation
With the dicator's son as our current President, I would expect a Heneral Luna-like movie about the dictator Ferdinand Marcos
That will surely come and it's inevitable that we will all watch that upcoming film in cinemas
As a movie that commits itself to be a Marcos apologist, Marcos symapathizing & a pro-Marcos propaganda film,"Maid In Malacañang" is actually a WEAK movie

With this fact, and in effect, this pro-Marcos movie can easily be refuted, debunked & belied by a bunch of new wave of anti-Marcos reply films that can successfully attack & destroy this Darryl Yap pro-Marcos film
Madaling pabulaanan ang "Maid In Malacañang" ng napakaraming reply films na darating sa susunod na taon
Director Darryl Yap through his pro-Marcos film is like taunting patriotic Filipinos to a fight but leaves himself very vulnerable to easily get defeated
Parang naghahamon ng away si Direk Darryl Yap sa napakaraming mga batikang director na mulat sa katotothanan ng Martial Law at marahas na diktadurya ni Marcos
Sa pamamagitan ng "Maid In Malacañang", nagbitiw ng isang suntok si Darryl Yap sa mga maka-Pilipinas na mga direktor
Subalit hindi malakas ang suntok ng kanyang pelikula kaya madaling matalo si Darryl Yap sa laban

So instead of winning the hearts and minds of the Filipino masses to the side of the Marcoses,"Maid In Malacañang" has opened a pandora's box of a massive bunch of a new wave of anti-Marcos films that will expose again the TRUTH about the brutal Marcos dictatorship

Few honest reviews, some shamelessly dishonest
The FILM does not pretend to be anything but a story of the final 72 hours of the Marcoses in Malacanang
It divides that story into 8 chapters, each chapter dealing with the interactions of the Family members and some helpers
It does not make the Marcos 'saintly' as others try to do other politicians
It paints a grim situation of how a family will deal with their fall and how they will survive that fall
It shows BETRAYALS in the beginning
There are expositions, dropped hints and each chapter attempts to draw emotions from the viewers in multiple directions
Overall, it entertains very well, which the movie intends to
It narrates and successfully so
It informs as well
The Very Good: Music, Sound, Photography, Acting, Screenplay
The Good - Direction, Script, EditingThe Average: Production Design, Continuity, In-Film Clips The Below Average: The use of TEXT for exposition
Should have consistently used Voice Narrations
